 resolve symbol 'nl_langinfo'
In-Reply-To: <042.b116567660f1fa025ff73160dc237f46@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.b116567660f1fa025ff73160dc237f46@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.dbc119971c48b37c3b5390895b7661fa@haiku-os.org>

#4747: runtime_loader ... Could not resolve symbol 'nl_langinfo'
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  scottmc       |       Owner:  zooey    
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/POSIX  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by zooey):

 Replying to [comment:4 kaliber]:
 > Zooey, where are you going to implement nl_types and others? In
 libroot.so or in liblocale.so? In the first case, libroot have to be
 linked against icu (bad), in the second one case a software should check
 for liblocale.

 Implementing it in libroot isn't necessarily bad, *if* the other POSIX
 locale stuff is implemented via ICU, too. But that has not been decided
 yet, and I can't tell now, because I do not know if ICU can be used to
 implement all the POSIX locale stuff and/or the functions declared in the
 three headers mentioned in this ticket. Time will tell, I guess ;-)

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4747#comment:5>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 13 20:43:56 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Super Dave Osbourne)
Date: Tue, 13 Oct 2009 18:43:56 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4776: VNC server and use of remote clipboard
 paste size bug limit to 63.9 Kilobytes of text.
Message-ID: <054.f264dc959b38e3a2a83349505afc8fa7@haiku-os.org>

#4776: VNC server and use of remote clipboard paste size bug limit to 63.9
Kilobytes of text.
---------------------------------+------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Super Dave Osbourne  |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug                  |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal               |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Servers              |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                       |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                       |  
---------------------------------+------------------------------------------
 Have verified with tests driving Pe and Styled Edit that getting data/text
 larger than 63.9 K i size from the clipboard to a application as well as
 from and onto the clipboard is the size limit regardless of various larger
 than 63.9 K copy and paste attempts.  The VNC server should be able to get
 whatever sized data is on the system clipboard, and also provide that same
 data to a remote VNC client.

 1.  Install and run the server of VNC for haiku, only the server.
 2.  Install and run a VNC client on your host.
 3.  Make a connection to the Haiku VM VNC server.
 4.  On local host open 1.5 meg file and copy all the text.
 5.  In connection window to the VM VNC server, open the Pe or StyledEdit
 apps.
 6.  In either app opened in #5, paste.
 7.  Witness the size limit, about 63.9K of text is pasted.

 Please fix this bug, it hampers remote boundary testing that I'm doing.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4776>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 13 21:03:36 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (axeld)
Date: Tue, 13 Oct 2009 19:03:36 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4778: kernel ignores reserved area too early
Message-ID: <040.9e7458a552d36cee6d643b95b14d3628@haiku-os.org>

#4778: kernel ignores reserved area too early
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  axeld          |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  critical       |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 I ran into the misbehaving Tracker again from time to time, so I added
 debugging info that helped me to track the issue down: Tracker threads are
 suddenly gone, because they need memory and cannot grow the heap anymore,
 as there is another area in the way for no reason; even if the address was
 full (which it is not), the reserved area should have caused the new area
 to go to its end, not its start.

 If the heap can shrink as well, another explanation could be that the
 reserved area does not contain the complete area after the heap anymore.

 Another problem seems to be that abort() does not cause the team to die in
 this case, only the thread goes away.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4778>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Tracker crashed after a bit. I then recorded the same scenario, with
 slightly different results, Tracker locking up pretty good, and finally
 when I closed all the info windows with (cntrl-w), Tracker and the system
 became unresponsive and had to power down the VM to get things working
 again.

 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Audio & Video  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Hello I installed haiku on a ibm thinkpad t23 laptop, Everything seems to
 be running fine except for the audio. Windows catergorizes the soundcard
 as a crystal soundcard while haiku says its an ac97 which I think linux
 also did which worked fine. I think I remember seeing references to ac97
 in the windows audio driver .inf file. Anyways here is this the problem I
 open up any mp3 or video file with the built in media player music will
 not play. I went to the media prefs to uncheck all the mutes and this
 still did not fix anything. When I press play on an mp3 file the status
 bar does not move at all to show its playing. I also tried using cl mp3
 player the winamp clone it did the same exact thing. Another weird thing
 is that if I unchecked mute microphone in media prefs haiku will broadcast
 the noises from the mic to my laptop speakers no problem so i guess it
 means the audio driver works okay? or somewhat okay... If you guys need
 any more info tell me what I need to do and i'll post back with that info

From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmlr)
Date: Tue, 13 Oct 2009 23:40:50 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4776: VNC server and use of remote
 clipboard paste size bug limit to 63.9 Kilobytes of text.
In-Reply-To: <054.f264dc959b38e3a2a83349505afc8fa7@haiku-os.org>
References: <054.f264dc959b38e3a2a83349505afc8fa7@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <063.6fafaf10762de323163837db675a8ef2@haiku-os.org>

#4776: VNC server and use of remote clipboard paste size bug limit to 63.9
Kilobytes of text.
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
  Reporter:  Super Dave Osbourne  |       Owner:  nobody   
      Type:  bug                  |      Status:  closed   
  Priority:  normal               |   Milestone:  R1       
 Component:  Servers              |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Resolution:  invalid              |   Blockedby:           
  Platform:  All                  |    Blocking:           
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
Changes (by mmlr):

  * status:  new => closed
  * resolution:  => invalid


Old description:

> Have verified with tests driving Pe and Styled Edit that getting
> data/text larger than 63.9 K i size from the clipboard to a application
> as well as from and onto the clipboard is the size limit regardless of
> various larger than 63.9 K copy and paste attempts.  The VNC server
> should be able to get whatever sized data is on the system clipboard, and
> also provide that same data to a remote VNC client.
>
> 1.  Install and run the server of VNC for haiku, only the server.
> 2.  Install and run a VNC client on your host.
> 3.  Make a connection to the Haiku VM VNC server.
> 4.  On local host open 1.5 meg file and copy all the text.
> 5.  In connection window to the VM VNC server, open the Pe or StyledEdit
> apps.
> 6.  In either app opened in #5, paste.
> 7.  Witness the size limit, about 63.9K of text is pasted.
>
> Please fix this bug, it hampers remote boundary testing that I'm doing.

New description:

 Have verified with tests driving Pe and Styled Edit that getting data/text
 larger than 63.9 K i size from the clipboard to a application as well as
 from and onto the clipboard is the size limit regardless of various larger
 than 63.9 K copy and paste attempts.  The VNC server should be able to get
 whatever sized data is on the system clipboard, and also provide that same
 data to a remote VNC client.

 {{{
 1.  Install and run the server of VNC for haiku, only the server.
 2.  Install and run a VNC client on your host.
 3.  Make a connection to the Haiku VM VNC server.
 4.  On local host open 1.5 meg file and copy all the text.
 5.  In connection window to the VM VNC server, open the Pe or StyledEdit
 apps.
 6.  In either app opened in #5, paste.
 7.  Witness the size limit, about 63.9K of text is pasted.
 }}}

 Please fix this bug, it hampers remote boundary testing that I'm doing.

--

Comment:

 Replying to [ticket:4776 Super Dave Osbourne]:
 > The VNC server should be able to get whatever sized data is on the
 system clipboard, and also provide that same data to a remote VNC client.

 Whatever VNC server you installed, it is not a part of Haiku. You should
 report the bug to either the VNC server or client developer, as the limit
 is imposed somewhere there. At least there is no such limit to be
 reproduced on a normal system.

 > Please fix this bug, it hampers remote boundary testing that I'm doing.

 Please drop this demanding attitude. Most bugs hamper with someones plans
 or work, that doesn't mean that there's anyone owing anyone else a bugfix
 because of that. I certainly admire the efforts you put into the testing
 automation, but this attitude just comes off pretty rude.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4776#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Something has changed between r33544 and r33575 which causes gcc4 builds
 to stop at the boot screen before any icons are lit.  This was observed
 with my own builds on real hardware and by testing nightly images from
 haiku-files via virtualbox.

 I tested:
 haiku-nightly-r33544-x86gcc4hybrid-raw.zip -- works
 haiku-nightly-r33575-x86gcc4hybrid-raw.zip -- doesn't boot

----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  axeld          |       Owner:  axeld         
      Type:  bug            |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  critical       |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Resolution:  fixed          |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  All            |    Blocking:  4780          
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
Changes (by axeld):

  * status:  new => closed
  * resolution:  => fixed


Comment:

 Thanks for the pointers, mmlr. r33037 was indeed to blame - you changed
 the way how areas are inserted into reserved areas without checking for
 their RESERVED_AVOID_BASE flag (which wasn't needed before, as that was
 the only insertion mode, only the comment above mentioned that flag).

 Anyway, the problem should be fixed in r33581.

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 14 13:21:16 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Wed, 14 Oct 2009 11:21:16 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4785: CTRL+Cursor word-wise jumping is tedious
Message-ID: <044.869f430cfc61b8d314e59884b9b77797@haiku-os.org>

#4785: CTRL+Cursor word-wise jumping is tedious
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger           |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  enhancement         |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Kits/Interface Kit  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 This is r33529.

 CTRL+CursorLeft/Right will jump word-wise through a text. Unfortuntely, a
 space and other textmarkings are treated as word and you therefore jump
 e.g. from the end of a word to the beginning of the next word.

 To illustrate, an example for CTRL+Right ("|" marks the cursor positions):

 "Haiku| |is| |a| |new| |open|-|source| |operating| |system|"


 This is, how it looks like in Pe or BeZilla:

 "Haiku| is| a| new| open-|source| operating| system|"


 Much more efficient, don't you agree?

 So, request: When jumping word-wise, ignore non-letter chars, like
 space,.-!"? etc.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4785>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 14 17:43:14 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (olaf)
Date: Wed, 14 Oct 2009 15:43:14 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4786: Terminal won't display text correctly
 with 'Glyph hinting' off
Message-ID: <039.5c80c239a8844335a5c500fbf6a12301@haiku-os.org>

#4786: Terminal won't display text correctly with 'Glyph hinting' off
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  olaf                   |       Owner:  jackburton    
     Type:  bug                    |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                 |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Terminal  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                         |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 If you turn 'Glyph hinting' off in the Preferences -> Appearance ->
 Antialiasing window, it causes problems with the Terminal application.
 After about the 20th character typed, the cursor will block view of what
 you're typing. You cannot see what you're typing in the terminal. This is
 with the default fonts, sizes, etc.

 My hardware is an Acer Aspire One AOA150. This bug has been in there since
 R1A1.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 14 20:15:48 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (olaf)
Date: Wed, 14 Oct 2009 18:15:48 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4787: Unticking "Horizontal Scrolling" does
 not disable horizontal scrolling
Message-ID: <039.f15e55ccd447a7fd0d5145ca91030e61@haiku-os.org>

#4787: Unticking "Horizontal Scrolling" does not disable horizontal scrolling
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  olaf         |       Owner:  nobody        
     Type:  bug          |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal       |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Preferences  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:               |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:               |  
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Unticking the "Horizontal Scrolling" option in the Trackpad Preferences
 window does not actually prevent horizontal scrolling. The only way to do
 that is to move the red line in the scrolling frame of the window down to
 the bottom.

 To test, untick it and you can scroll Back in BeZillaBrowser by moving
 horizontally left.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4787>

Comment(by V!NCENT):

 I have the same problem on the Eee PC 900.

 It booted without anything disabled in the BIOS prior to the 13th of
 August r32334 version. The last know working version was the 12th of
 August r32290 version.

 The system hang at startup, and therefore was not installed, at the fourth
 icon. The last two onscreen debug output lines from the 13th of October
 version r33585-x86gcc2hybrid before the complete system hang were:
 ata 0: _DevicePresent: device selection failed for device 0
 ata 0: _DevicePresent: device 1. presence 0

 No errors were displayed prior to the last two lines.

 After that line is displayed the read/write activity LED on the USB stick
 stopped flashing indicating that nothing happens afterwards.

 It doesn't matter if some/all onboard devices are de disabled in the BIOS.
 It doesn't matter what boot paramiters are checked at the Haiku safeboot
 screen by pressing the spacebar prior to startup.

 The BIOS option OS Installation [start] was used.

 The latest (as of 14 October 2009) Win32 Disk Imager tool was used under
 Windows to write RAW images to a brandless 1GB USB stick.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 14 22:25:18 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (phoudoin)
Date: Wed, 14 Oct 2009 20:25:18 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
In-Reply-To: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
References: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <055.14000c3e14e18341b2593a368c2612f8@haiku-os.org>

#4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  blocker        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by phoudoin):

 Seems since r33547 the (mutex), (recursive_lock) and (rw_lock) casts are
 interpreted by gcc4 as the ones tydef'ined in the new
 headers/private/shared/locks.h, not the usual
 headers/private/kernel/lock.h ones.
 Maybe gcc2.95.3 and gcc4 includes order is not exactly the same.
 Or maybe I'm just blind stupid, dunno yet.

 Anyway, having two different typedef'ed mutex structs doesn't sound like a
 good idea, except if we take some measure to warrant that they can't be
 used in wrong context (kernel vs userland).
 Doesn't seems the case currently.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4782#comment:10>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 15 02:22:02 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmlr)
Date: Thu, 15 Oct 2009 00:22:02 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
In-Reply-To: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
References: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <055.79ab814bc099fe34fd714a21217eba93@haiku-os.org>

#4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  blocker        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by mmlr):

 locks.h is included by exactly one file in the whole tree:
 src/system/libroot/posix/malloc_debug/heap.cpp the two headers also don't
 have the same name (lock.h vs. locks.h). If it is indeed included and used
 then something's very wrong. There are a few shared headers between
 libroot and the kernel, but this isn't the case for this one and I
 wouldn't know how it could happen. It's easily verified if the header is
 included by adding an #error directive to it and check if the kernel still
 builds with that.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4782#comment:11>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 15 04:30:57 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmlr)
Date: Thu, 15 Oct 2009 02:30:57 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
In-Reply-To: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
References: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <055.474f32531eb9b8d417a5f5aff9039952@haiku-os.org>

#4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  blocker        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by mmlr):

 That's what I've found:

 It doesn't boot because it runs into a "PANIC: _mutex_lock(): double lock
 of..." which is caused by an uninitialized mutex (sObjectCacheListLock in
 Slab.cpp). The contents of that mutex are all 0. Taking it further apart,
 it is all 0 because the variable ends up in the .bss section. This was not
 the case before, where it would end up in the .data section instead and be
 properly initialized (the includes are fine btw, the preprocessed output
 looks exactly as expected).

 Research shows that what we do now is called a compound literal:
 http://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-3.3.1/gcc/Compound-Literals.html

 As it is described there, that this is supported for static variables is
 only a GCC extension. Either they changed their mind since then, or it is
 a bug/regression in the GCC4 we are using. I've looked over their
 bugzilla, but nothing really pointing in that direction turned up. I
 didn't look too closely though. I did also not find any workarounds to
 achieve the desired effect.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4782#comment:12>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 15 08:53:57 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (bbjimmy)

Comment(by humdinger):

 Having used Mail for a month now as my sole email client, I have to say, I
 don't see the sense in the "Mail" and "Inbox" icons in the toolbar. never
 used them, never missed them. Even more so, since "Mail" doesn't respect
 the current account (see this ticket) and "Inbox" actually does the same
 as clicking the mail_daemon icon in the Deskbar: launching the
 ~/config/settings/Mail/mailbox link, which not necessarily opens the inbox
 (mine queries for new mail).

 So: Kill both icons. :)

Comment(by humdinger):

 I, at least, wouldn't like that. Inboxes tend to swell over time. I
 (almost) never open an inbox folder as watching how the folder fills up
 for several seconds and then sitting there with 10.000 mails isn't
 helping... :)

 Instead I use queries to find new mail, mail with the custom status
 "4later", and "Last 2 weeks" (as Query template). Plus a folder with
 queries for certain mailing list mails of the last week.

 IMO, no need for the inbox folder of every account directly accessible
 from the mail_daemon symbol in the deskbar.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 15 14:14:10 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (delroth)
Date: Thu, 15 Oct 2009 12:14:10 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4790: PANIC on USB boot with CS5536 chipset
Message-ID: <042.121f2100cb59f4dab62c54588a78f255@haiku-os.org>

#4790: PANIC on USB boot with CS5536 chipset
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  delroth        |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 I get a kernel panic (unable to find boot partitions) when booting Haiku
 from my USB drive (with a sufficient size, that is not the source of the
 problem).

 From the on-screen debugging output (no camera, no serial output, so I
 can't provide screenshots or whatever else) :
 {{{
 usb uhci: no defices found
 usb ohci -1: iospace offset: 0xeff00000
 usb ohci -1: smm is in control of the host controller
 usb ohci -1: ownership change successful
 usb ohci -1: successfully started the controller
 usb ehci -1: claiming ownership of the host controller
 usb ehci -1: successfully took ownership of the host controller
 usb ehci -1: successfully started the controller
 usb hub 2: port 1: device removed
 usb hub 2: port 2: device removed
 usb hub 7: port 1: new device connected
 usb error control pipe 11: timeout waiting for queued request to complete
 usb error control pipe 11: timeout waiting for queued request to complete
 usb error ehci 1: qtd (0x02522580) error: 0x00B80248
 usb error control pipe 11: timeout waiting for queued request to complete
 usb error ehci 1: qtd (0x02522780) error: 0x00B80240
 usb error ehci 1: error while setting device address
 }}}

 After this point, the kernel searches for the boot partition and
 (obviously) do not find anything.

 Reproduced the problem on both R1/A1 and last SVN.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4790>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 > {{{
 > int  10, enabled 2, handled        1, unhandled        0
 >        ehci:(C++ mangling for InterruptHandler)
 >        ohci:(C++ mangling for InterruptHandler)
 > }}}

 other hand it is also > 0. It's a bit hard to tell. If you have another
 way of booting and could check if other devices do indeed work, that'd be
 most informative. You could also try removing the EHCI driver and see if
 OHCI takes over gracefully (it should, it'd just be slower).

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 15 16:21:43 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmlr)
Date: Thu, 15 Oct 2009 14:21:43 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4790: PANIC on USB boot with CS5536
	chipset
In-Reply-To: <042.121f2100cb59f4dab62c54588a78f255@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.121f2100cb59f4dab62c54588a78f255@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.bed761beb52db7d08712acd5d3323d79@haiku-os.org>

#4790: PANIC on USB boot with CS5536 chipset
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  delroth        |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by mmlr):

 If you're building a new image to dd to the medium then you could remove
 "<usb>ehci" from build/jam/HaikuImage. If you're updating an existing
 image/filesystem then you need to remove system/add-
 ons/kernel/busses/usb/ehci. You could do that using the mount pseudo-
 target like "jam @yourTargetBuildProfile mount" which should then bring up
 the target in the fsshell. From there you can remove said file.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4790#comment:6>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Reporter:  humdinger             |       Owner:  czeidler

----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 This is r33599.

 Touchpad's preference panel looks a bit cramped.[[BR]]
 Maybe the Mouse preference panel could be used as a template. This would
 improve the look and make all more consistent.

 The bold "Scrolling" and "Tap Gesture" aren't really needed IMO.

 The Tap Click Sensitivity could use a try-out-area, like a light bulp that
 lights up when clicked.

 The use of capital letters should be reviewed (in Mouse as well). I think
 the common practice is to just capitalize the first word, e.g. "Scroll
 acceleration" or "Two finger scrolling".

 How about a bubble help for the "Two finger scrolling"? How does it work?

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 15 22:22:54 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmlr)
Date: Thu, 15 Oct 2009 20:22:54 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
In-Reply-To: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
References: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <055.85762de31b04e1f0e139523457eed2ae@haiku-os.org>

#4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld         
      Type:  bug            |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  blocker        |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Resolution:  fixed          |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  x86            |    Blocking:                
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------

Comment(by mmlr):

 I was about to file a bug report at the GCC bugzilla, but after trying to
 distill out a simpler testcase I now know what is actually going on. The
 initializer is still there, but the initialization of the locks at hand
 aren't done by putting them in the data section anymore. Instead the init
 is moved to the __static_initialization_and_destruction function. We don't
 call this init function in the kernel. If it is safe to call it, then we
 should probably just do it. I am not sure how safe it is to be called in
 early kernel startup, but it can basically be just initializing variables
 to constant values, so unproblematic.

 The problem is that there is not a single init function for obvious
 reasons. Looking at a kernel disassembly there are currently 14 instances
 of such a function spread for various files. Judging simply by the fact
 that there are such functions, we probably miss some static init in GCC4
 right now.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4782#comment:15>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 15 23:15:45 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (nonne)
Date: Thu, 15 Oct 2009 21:15:45 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4792: Middle button functionally
Message-ID: <040.0db59930174d0ff08f2f98b1ce5b9702@haiku-os.org>

#4792: Middle button functionally
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  nonne           |       Owner:  stippi   
     Type:  enhancement     |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal          |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  User Interface  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                  |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                  |  
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 The middle button isn't really much used currently in Haiku, so I have
 been thinking about how it could be used to speed upp some tasks for the
 poweruser. One nice thing would be to use it for moving windows in the
 background or just give a backround app focus without bring it to front.
 Another thing it could do is to let the user select options in a menu
 without closing it. As an example at the deskbar if i would like to select
 24 hour clock, show seconds and european date in deskbar settings I could
 this much faster because the menu wouldn't close when I select an option.
 The middle button could also be used to open folders in new windows if you
 have choosen single window navigation or in the same window if you use
 default navigation. It would also reverse the the move/copy dragging
 compared to the left button. Would it be easy to implement this behaviour
 to Haiku? I think it would be really useful for speeding up things for the
 user.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4792>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

#4792: Middle button functionally
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  nonne        |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  enhancement  |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal       |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Preferences  |     Version:  R1/alpha1

Comment(by bonefish):

 Calling the global static initialization should be OK in principle. We
 should check whether there are static kernel variables (with complex
 constructors) for which the constructors are expected not to be called
 automatically, though. Also, we should call the module constructors and
 destructors.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 16 11:31:39 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (bonefish)
Date: Fri, 16 Oct 2009 09:31:39 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
In-Reply-To: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
References: <046.28780615cff86e78ae59cebeba07677a@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <055.025c74f33f503702f4ea58612689453d@haiku-os.org>

#4782: gcc4 builds fail to boot
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld         
      Type:  bug            |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  blocker        |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Resolution:  fixed          |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  x86            |    Blocking:                
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------

Comment(by bonefish):

 Replying to [comment:17 axeld]:
 > How to check for complex constructors, though?

 How about using objdump to find out which ones are (should be called) and
 reading their source code?

 > And when to call them?

 At some point early in the boot process. I suppose normally static
 constructors won't do much besides initializing some data structures, so
 that shouldn't matter all that much. Stuff like memory allocations aren't
 suitable for constructors anyway.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4782#comment:18>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 16 23:27:18 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (augiedoggie)
Date: Fri, 16 Oct 2009 21:27:18 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4794: [StyledEdit] doesn't handle "be:line"
	in RefsReceived
Message-ID: <046.c82bde60a88240a6101502d96a12ad28@haiku-os.org>

#4794: [StyledEdit] doesn't handle "be:line" in RefsReceived
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  augiedoggie              |       Owner:  korli    
     Type:  bug                      |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Applications/StyledEdit  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 In BeOS, both StyledEdit and the BeIDE editor were able to handle a line
 number to scroll to and select when opening the file.  This was sent in
 the B_REFS_RECEIVED message by adding an int32 with a name of "be:line"
 and the value being the line number.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4794>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>

 I'm trying to get emacs running on haiku, after two days I got it to
 compile, but when trying to bootstrap emacs, I receive this backtrace
 after emacs has opened 5 other files using the same
 code path.

 nightly. I'm using gcc4 to compile emacs.

 Reporter:  ikoli            |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/Network  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                   |

Comment(by umccullough):

 Just to be clear, you're sure when you set static IP that you assigned a
 gateway and DNS server(s)?

 You can verify they're set properly with a "route print" and "cat
 /etc/resolv.conf" I believe.

 Other options are to ping your gateway, and ping your DNS servers to see
 if that works.

--

Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Oct 17 01:53:12 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (rogueeve)
Date: Fri, 16 Oct 2009 23:53:12 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4796: Deskbar freeze: BMenu and workspace
	interactions
Message-ID: <043.fed804fd69d0108b4af56d67d47f38b7@haiku-os.org>

#4796: Deskbar freeze: BMenu and workspace interactions
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  rogueeve            |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug                 |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Kits/Interface Kit  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Ok, I'll admit I experimented specifically looking for this one, but it
 still isn't quite right.

 Open one of the menus on the Deskbar. You can click the Haiku leaf, or you
 can open one of the pop-open menus for an open application. While the menu
 is open, use a keyboard shortcut such as cmd+~ or cmd+f2 to switch the
 workspace away. The menu will disappear, but the deskbar will become
 completely unresponsive. If a submenu is open when you switch away, it
 will glitch graphically as well.

 I observed other odd albeit non-fatal behavior in other applications as
 well (check menus on Tracker windows, they get stuck open), so I think the
 problem may be that BMenus can partially close but do not properly notify
 the app if the workspace is switched away. So I'm filing it under
 interface kit.

 My revision is r33565.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4796>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 "taskbar" mode across the bottom or top of the screen. If the Deskbar is
 in it's default position, the button still shows down, but it does not
 lock up.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Oct 17 10:19:17 2009

In-Reply-To: <041.d9ea037de0469b2f6d34adab9191909f@haiku-os.org>

#4795: segfault in the internals of malloc after emacs fdopen()s for the 6th time
--------------------+-------------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  alexbl  |       Owner:  nobody       
     Type:  bug     |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal  |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  System  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:          |    Platform:  x86          
 Blocking:          |

Changes (by alexbl):

  * version:  R1/alpha1 => R1/pre-alpha1


Comment:

 I got further into the process (I have something close to working I
 think), by getting emacs to use SYSTEM_MALLOC instead of its own malloc().
 I believe that emacs' malloc was causing memory corruption after some help
 from the folks on haiku-development at . I still think that this is a bug,
 (that using the emacs supplied malloc causes nasty issue), but I don't
 think it's a priority or anything.

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Oct 17 18:39:51 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Sat, 17 Oct 2009 16:39:51 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4798: Query result isn't removed when queried
 object is put into Trash
Message-ID: <044.2bc4d744164538723a83c903706c584b@haiku-os.org>

#4798: Query result isn't removed when queried object is put into Trash
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger         |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug               |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Kits/Storage Kit  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                    |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                    |  
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 This is r33599.

  * Create a New Folder on the Desktop.
  * Create therein a file, name it "froody".
  * Open the find panel and query for "froody".
  * Delete the newly created folder (move it to Trash).

 Now the query result window should reflect that by removing the entry of
 froody with the path /boot/home/Desktop/New Folder/ and instead show it in
 /boot/home/Desktop/Trash/New Folder/ (or at least remove the entry, if you
 exclude the Trash from the query).
 But it doesn't.

 Emptying the Trash will correctly remove the entry.

 If you leave out the folder from that procedure, i.e. delete the queried
 object directly, everything works as expected.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4798>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

> This is a general ticket to track progress on internationalization. It
> only track the sourcecode and jamfiles part, not the availability of
> languages (this probably belongs outside of tracker)
>

> == Done ==
>  * Appearance preflet (uses BColorControl which features untranslated
> "Red:", "Green:" and "Blue:")
>  * Bluetooth preflet
>  * CPU Frequency preflet
>  * Fonts preflet
>  * Locale preflet
>

>  * DataTranslation preflet : layout kit

>  * Dial-up networking preflet : layout kit

>
> == Not done ==
>  * Everything else for now.

New description:

 This is a general ticket to track progress on internationalization. It
 only track the sourcecode and jamfiles part, not the availability of
 languages (this probably belongs outside of tracker)


 == Done ==
  * Appearance preflet (uses BColorControl which features untranslated
 "Red:", "Green:" and "Blue:")
  * Bluetooth preflet
  * CPU Frequency preflet
  * Fonts preflet
  * Locale preflet

 == Skipped ==
  * Background preflet : needs to use layout kit
  * DataTranslation preflet : layout kit
  * Devices preflet : layout kit
  * Dial-up networking preflet : layout kit
  * FileTypes preflet : layout kit
  * Joystick preflet : layout kit
  * Keyboard preflet : layout kit

 == Not done ==
  * Everything else for now.

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 18 11:12:58 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mpanasyuk)
Date: Sun, 18 Oct 2009 09:12:58 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4801: [BePDF] Document window visible on all
	workspaces
Message-ID: <044.a8400f81118f47495b4774fb8cc413e8@haiku-os.org>

#4801: [BePDF] Document window visible on all workspaces
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mpanasyuk     |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Applications  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Switching to fullscreen mode and then back to window mode makes program
 window visible on all workspaces.

 If you switch to fullscreen mode again then window again becames visible
 only on one workspace. Switching back to window mode again makes it
 visible on all workspaces.

 Expected behaviour:
 In all modes document window always visible only on one workspace.

--

Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 18 13:58:40 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (pulkomandy)
Date: Sun, 18 Oct 2009 11:58:40 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4239: msk driver network connection
 quickly becomes unresponsive
In-Reply-To: <041.46cfbf09b605923b5aa837eb95cd8056@haiku-os.org>
References: <041.46cfbf09b605923b5aa837eb95cd8056@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <050.398eb493a4bc20077a3ea5c336159488@haiku-os.org>

#4239: msk driver network connection quickly becomes unresponsive
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Keifer           |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/Network  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------

Comment(by pulkomandy):

 Some more information :

  * These are the OpenBSD sourcecode, for reference :
 http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb/src/sys/dev/mii/eephy.c?rev=1.48
 ;content-type=text%2Fplain
 http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb/src/sys/dev/mii/mii.h?rev=1.11
 ;content-type=text%2Fplain
 http://www.openbsd.org/cgi-bin/cvsweb/src/sys/dev/pci/if_msk.c?rev=1.79
 ;content-type=text%2Fplain
  * Philippe Houdoin also encounters the problem and did some
 investigations. This is a gigabyte chip downgraded to fast ethernet, and
 they just did it wrong. There are a lot of hacks needed to get it working
 properly. The Gigabyte version should work fine. The problem is in the PHY
 layer.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4239#comment:6>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 18 16:17:11 2009

#4804: integrating malloc_debug
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmadia             |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  enhancement        |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/libroot.so  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 [http://www.freelists.org/post/haiku-development/weird-segfault-in-malloc-
 internals-when-trying-to-call-fdopen,17 This haiku-development ML thread]
 mentions integrating src/system/libroot/posix/malloc_debug and possibly
 making it available as a runtime setting. This which will allow it to be
 enabled and configured dynamically.

 For now, malloc_debug can be enabled by switching over the malloc to the
 malloc_debug directory in the src/system/libroot/posix/Jamfile and
 rebuilding libroot. It can also do leak checking and does initialize and
 overwrite freed memory with known values to make access to these more
 obvious.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4804>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 18 18:24:00 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Sun, 18 Oct 2009 16:24:00 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4805: Sounds preference panel improvements
Message-ID: <044.2b1247e138caf5c77fe40e52ea5d469b@haiku-os.org>

#4805: Sounds preference panel improvements
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger           |       Owner:  marcusoverhagen
     Type:  enhancement         |      Status:  new            
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1             
Component:  Preferences/Sounds  |     Version:  R1/Development 
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All            
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Here's a suggestion to improve the Sounds preferences panel.

 The panel now (r33599):[[BR]]
 [[Image:sounds-pref-now.png]]

 My suggestion mockup:[[BR]]
 [[Image:sounds-pref-suggestion.png]]

 On top, there's a dropdown menu with already saved profiles plus the entry
 "Save current profile..." which will open a panel to enter a profile
 name.[[BR]]
 Pressing the trash symbol will delete the currently set profile. When
 there's <none>, the symbol is "ghosted".[[BR]]
 It would be nice if there'd be a "Toggle mute all" profile preconfigured
 that would overlay the existing settings. I.e., the sound file selection
 is kept, but every event is muted/unmuted.[[BR]]
 Sound profiles and window setting should be kept in
 ~/config/settings/Sounds/.

 There's a new column "Mute" where you can quickly mute an event without
 having to choose "<none> for it and later having to find and set the sound
 file again. The symbol appearing then is supposed to be a stroked speaker.
 Could be improved...

 Besides using MediaPlayers controls to play/pause/stop there's also its
 volume bar. Every individual sound file's volume can be controled with
 this widget. For this, an attribute is saved to the sound file.

 The panel should start larger than it is now and save its window position.

 Not visible: The open file dialog should provide a play/pause "pre-listen"
 button so you can hear it right there instead of again and again having to
 load/close/play/open when looking for a sound.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4805>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

New description:

 Here's a suggestion to improve the Sounds preferences panel.

 The panel now (r33599):[[BR]]
 [[Image(sounds-pref-now.png)]]

 My suggestion mockup:[[BR]]
 [[Image(sounds-pref-suggestion.png)]]

 On top, there's a dropdown menu with already saved profiles plus the entry
 "Save current profile..." which will open a panel to enter a profile
 name.[[BR]]
 Pressing the trash symbol will delete the currently set profile. When
 there's <none>, the symbol is "ghosted".[[BR]]
 It would be nice if there'd be a "Toggle mute all" profile preconfigured
 that would overlay the existing settings. I.e., the sound file selection
 is kept, but every event is muted/unmuted.[[BR]]
 Sound profiles and window setting should be kept in
 ~/config/settings/Sounds/.

 There's a new column "Mute" where you can quickly mute an event without
 having to choose "<none> for it and later having to find and set the sound
 file again. The symbol appearing then is supposed to be a stroked speaker.
 Could be improved...

 Besides using MediaPlayers controls to play/pause/stop there's also its
 volume bar. Every individual sound file's volume can be controled with
 this widget. For this, an attribute is saved to the sound file.

 The panel should start larger than it is now and save its window position.

 Not visible: The open file dialog should provide a play/pause "pre-listen"
 button so you can hear it right there instead of again and again having to
 load/close/play/open when looking for a sound.

--

The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 18 18:52:58 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (delroth)
Date: Sun, 18 Oct 2009 16:52:58 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4806: Netbook native screen resolution not
	detected
Message-ID: <042.150393a1469e21f36c8be8937e4ce6ec@haiku-os.org>

#4806: Netbook native screen resolution not detected
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  delroth           |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug               |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/Graphics  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                    |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                    |  
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Haiku is using a default resolution of 1024x768 on my netbook while its
 native resolution is 800x480. As a consequence, all the pixels outside the
 screen are not visible (while I can move the mouse there, etc.).

 The netbook is Geode-based, with this video card (in listdev output) :
 {{{
 device Display controller (VGA compatible controller, VGA controller)
 [3|0|0]
   vendor 1022: Advanced Micro Devices [AMD]
   device 2081: Geode LX Video
 }}}

 r33636, the October 18 revision, introduced a new bug on my AOA150-1786.
 It only allows 800x600 for the resolution, but it should be able to do
 1024x600 -- the native resolution. r33610 (yesterday's revision) did not
 have this bug.

 Aside from only doing 800x600, it shows the desktop "tiled". 800 pixels of
 the desktop + 224 more pixels of the desktop again (to make up for the
 1024 width it's SUPPOSED to show).

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4750: [ Matrox driver ] DVI
 detection/routing problem (DVI port doesn't work correctly)

correctly)

 Reporter:  starsseed                |       Owner:  rudolfc

 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------

Comment(by rudolfc):

 Ah, OK, now I see.

 Does it still show no video on DVI if you delete the vesa settings file,
 and the app_server settings file?
 Haiku will try 1024x768 then..

 If you first connect your screen to the analog port, select a mode above
 1280x1024 using Screen prefs, then reboot with the monitor now connected
 to the DVI port, Haiku will try the resolution you just set.. And will
 fail.

 Is this the case on your system?

 Thanks for answering in advance..
 Rudolf.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Oct 19 08:37:20 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Pete)
Date: Mon, 19 Oct 2009 06:37:20 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4053: USB MIDI not recognized dynamically
In-Reply-To: <039.f45ca5c1dca5eb2ff5063d3c574fbcb7@haiku-os.org>
References: <039.f45ca5c1dca5eb2ff5063d3c574fbcb7@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <048.67679252141b701f6cdfb0d93a5ede33@haiku-os.org>

#4053: USB MIDI not recognized dynamically
---------------------------------+------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Pete                 |       Owner:  phoudoin     
     Type:  bug                  |      Status:  assigned     
 Priority:  normal               |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Servers/midi_server  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                       |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                       |  
---------------------------------+------------------------------------------

Comment(by Pete):

 Finally...(!)
 A slight reorganization of the objects used by usb_midi seems to have at
 last given stable handling of USB MIDI plugging and unplugging. It no
 longer steps the device number when replugged, either.  I've attached a
 patch against (approximately) the alpha1 sources.  [The reference sources
 are the berlios.de source snapshot of 2009/9/28,
 but nobody has yet been able to tell me how to find the revision number of
 this (:-/)]

 The main fix was to make the usb device info structure and the driver
 cookie a little more independent of each other, and to carefully
 disconnect them before either is deleted.

 I also (eventually) realized that one thing bedevilling me ''was'' a bug
 in legacy_drivers that had been fixed independently (ticket #3856), so
 things work a bit better under alpha1!

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4053#comment:39>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

  Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld

  Priority:  blocker        |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Resolution:  fixed          |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  x86            |    Blocking:                
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------

Comment(by axeld):

 Replying to [comment:18 bonefish]:
 > How about using objdump to find out which ones are (should be called)
 and reading their source code?

 Hm, I would prefer a more clear/descriptive mechanism, like putting them
 into a different ELF section, and then skip them when calling the
 constructors.

 > > And when to call them?
 > At some point early in the boot process. I suppose normally static
 constructors won't do much besides initializing some data structures, so
 that shouldn't matter all that much. Stuff like memory allocations aren't
 suitable for constructors anyway.

 True enough.

--

Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Oct 19 21:40:26 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (olaf)
Date: Mon, 19 Oct 2009 19:40:26 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4812: Screen Saver 'Password lock' security
	weakness
Message-ID: <039.da6349c423a8215cf2cd313aa56641e8@haiku-os.org>

#4812: Screen Saver 'Password lock' security weakness
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  olaf                     |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                      |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Preferences/ScreenSaver  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 If you use the '''Password lock''' security feature, only the first 8
 characters need to be guessed to unlock it. Any characters past the first
 8 are ignored.

 Example: your password is "1234567890" but it can be unlocked with
 "12345678" only.

 This was tested in r33610.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4812>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 20 03:47:59 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (axeld)
Date: Tue, 20 Oct 2009 01:47:59 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4815: B_OP_COPY does not work as advertized
	anymore
Message-ID: <040.aeca028e37b839f038937dc07aada7b1@haiku-os.org>

#4815: B_OP_COPY does not work as advertized anymore
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  axeld               |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                 |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Servers/app_server  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 This is a problem of how to deal with anti-aliasing. The current solution
 is to more or less ignore B_OP_COPY, and apply the aliasing  by taking the
 destination into account.

 However, this leads to unwanted results (namely the anti-aliased pixels
 get darker and darker with each redraw).

 Just using this ticket as a discussion on how to solve this the best way.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4815>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

#4704: [Twitcher] Arrow drawing artifacts

From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 20 10:02:47 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (stippi)
Date: Tue, 20 Oct 2009 08:02:47 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4815: B_OP_COPY does not work as
	advertized anymore
In-Reply-To: <040.aeca028e37b839f038937dc07aada7b1@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.aeca028e37b839f038937dc07aada7b1@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.f2d554614034f5d1aa90696b372e9fdd@haiku-os.org>

#4815: B_OP_COPY does not work as advertized anymore
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  axeld               |       Owner:  stippi        
     Type:  bug                 |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Servers/app_server  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------

Comment(by stippi):

 Well, for a long time after the initial implementation, B_OP_COPY worked
 exactly as advertised for text rendering, only also for all the other
 primitives. Since you didn't need to be aware of the problem for other
 primitives on BeOS, existing apps usually do not set the low color to the
 correct color before stroking a line for example. Or they stroke a line
 using the low color onto a background of another color. Even for text
 rendering, many developers didn't get this right and you could often see
 text being rendered with the wrong background color, like a white low
 color onto an actually gray background. For all these reasons, I decided
 that B_OP_COPY only works as before for text rendering, for everything
 else, it works like B_OP_OVER. The draw-back is the one you describe in
 this ticket, but obviously it is a far less common problem than apps using
 B_OP_COPY in the wrong way because it didn't matter on R5. I leave it up
 to you to mark this as invalid or not. At least I don't really see a way
 to fix this, since app_server cannot tell if something would look bad or
 not and change behavior accordingly.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4815#comment:2>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Does B_OP_COPY still work as advertised for text? I ask because I noticed
 the text in a tracker query seems to suffer from the anti-aliasing
 darkening when the window is resized.

 Perhaps a solution would be to add a BView flag to enable anti-aliased
 primitives, which could be set by default in the Haiku headers so new apps
 would look nice, but would ensure R5 apps render as before. I suppose it's
 a choice between making most things look better, or shooting for exact
 pixel-for-pixel compatibility with R5 (not hugely important, IMHO)

From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 20 23:27:20 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmlr)
Date: Tue, 20 Oct 2009 21:27:20 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4817: Zip-O-Matic Possible Usability
	Enhancement
Message-ID: <039.af33c7a9e8c1b476ebcdc4e2914e7c23@haiku-os.org>

#4817: Zip-O-Matic Possible Usability Enhancement
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  mmlr             |       Owner:  jonas.kirilla
     Type:  enhancement      |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Add-Ons/Tracker  |     Version:  R1/alpha1    
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 If you start Zip-O-Matic as a Tracker add-on and then drag some files onto
 it, it will create the zip in the same folder the files you drag are in.
 If you drag files from a query though, you don't necessarily have that
 "source" folder open, neither do the files necessarily come from the same
 folder at all. It would be nice if there was a way for the output zip to
 be more visible. Three possible changes we came up with:

 1) It could open the target folder when zipping completes (like expander
 does in the opposite case)

 2) It could provide a draggable icon in it's window that represents the
 resulting zip file

 3) It could always create the zip in the directory where-from the add-on
 was invoked

 The third option would make it a bit easier to grasp the behaviour. It
 would make it easy to specify the target directory just by invoking the
 add-on from there.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4817>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Comment(by tonestone57):

 This hardware should work.  My motherboard has the same network card and
 works great for me.  My hardware (ethernet card) is listed in this ticket:
 http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4287

 I would think you are having some type of configuration issue.  Try going
 into BIOS and changing to On with PXE boot.  See if that does anything for
 you.  Like what happened here:
 http://www.haiku-os.org/community/forum/ipro100_nic_problems

 If you can ping your router, ie: 192.168.1.1, then networking is working
 and you have a DNS issue to figure out.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 21 02:42:08 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (plodder)
Date: Wed, 21 Oct 2009 00:42:08 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4819: Haiku changes active partition when
 dual booting from GRUB
Message-ID: <042.34dbccc6cbdaedfe8d8991039b19f04e@haiku-os.org>

#4819: Haiku changes active partition when dual booting from GRUB
---------------------+------------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  plodder  |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug      |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal   |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System   |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:           |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:           |  
---------------------+------------------------------------------------------
 I have installed Haiku Alpha 1 for dual booting with PC Linux OS via GRUB
 on an Acer 529ATX laptop. The current setup of the partitions is as
 follows:

 primary partition 1: Haiku Alpha 1

 primary partition 2: PC Linux OS

 Active partition: primary partition 2

 Boot loader: GRUB installed on primary partition 2.

 The set up works perfectly and I can boot into both PC Linux OS and Haiku
 without problems - except for one glitch. When I boot into Haiku, it
 changes the active partition (boot flag) from partition 2 to partition 1.
 Thus, on the next boot, GRUB is bypassed, the option to boot into PC Linux
 OS is not presented and the laptop boots directly into Haiku. If I want to
 boot into PC Linux OS, I have to change the active partition (boot flag)
 back to primary partition 2 using, e.g., cfdisk on the Parted Magic CD
 first.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4819>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

References: <040.b8ed9934219f9f136a4b7b22150cf3bc@haiku-os.org>

#4751: network with 8169 driver
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  ikoli            |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/Network  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------

Comment(by nos):

 Thanks tonestone57 I have it working now I change 2 things at once in bios
 and when I booted Haiku it worked :)

 For others with gigabyte GA-P35-DS3/S3 mother board
 2 things I did was select the option in the bios for "Smart Lan" and place
 "boot on lan" as the third boot device. don't know why that would cause it
 to work after checking my manual again or placing lan as a boot option
 even after the hard drive

 Will try to confirm if this is indeed "zvzcet" ticket as he has "Smart
 Lan" option under bios as well (just downloaded his motherboard manual)

 Thanks again

#4549: PANIC: Unexpected exception "Divide Error Exception" occurred in kernel
mode! Error code: 0x0
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  xray7224       |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by axeld):

 If that is reproducible, can you post your syslog, as well as a stack
 crawl from that panic? To do that, just type "sc" <enter> in the kernel
 debugger, and then "syslog" <enter>. You can either add screenshots from
 that, or enable serial output in the boot loader (by pressing space before
 the Haiku splash screen appears during boot, and select it in the safe-
 mode options), and configure VirtualBox to put the serial output to some
 place usable (like a file). Thanks in advance!

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4549#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 21 10:42:34 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (axeld)
Date: Wed, 21 Oct 2009 08:42:34 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4824: BTextView::LineWidth doesn't take

      Type:  bug            |      Status:  closed        
  Priority:  blocker        |   Milestone:  R1            
 Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/Development
Resolution:  fixed          |   Blockedby:                
  Platform:  x86            |    Blocking:                
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------

Comment(by axeld):

 Replying to [comment:20 bonefish]:
 > > Hm, I would prefer a more clear/descriptive mechanism, like putting
 them into a different ELF section, and then skip them when calling the
 constructors.
 > What "them" do you mean? I thought we're talking about constructors, but
 then your sentence doesn't make sense.

 It did to me ;-) When we move constructors into a separate segment, the
 constructor calling code could ignore them, giving you the opportunity to
 initialize them manually.

 > Other than that, we could put the static constructors into a separate
 segment and free it after kernel initialization.

 Yes, even though that would probably only be a few KB, Linux does that as
 well, btw.

Comment(by bonefish):

 Replying to [comment:21 axeld]:
 > Replying to [comment:20 bonefish]:
 > > > Hm, I would prefer a more clear/descriptive mechanism, like putting
 them into a different ELF section, and then skip them when calling the
 constructors.
 > > What "them" do you mean? I thought we're talking about constructors,
 but then your sentence doesn't make sense.
 >
 > It did to me ;-) When we move constructors into a separate segment, the
 constructor calling code could ignore them, giving you the opportunity to
 initialize them manually.

 The constructor calling code -- I assume you mean crtbegin.o, which we
 don't even link against ATM -- shall ignore the constructors, so we can
 invoke them manually? Sorry, I'm still at a loss.

 > > Other than that, we could put the static constructors into a separate
 segment and free it after kernel initialization.
 >
 > Yes, even though that would probably only be a few KB, Linux does that
 as well, btw.

 I wouldn't only put the constructors in there, but all initialization
 code. That's probably more than only a few KB.

 PS: Let's take further discussion to a more suitable place.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 21 14:38:09 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Adek336)
Date: Wed, 21 Oct 2009 12:38:09 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4825: BSoundPlayer segv
Message-ID: <042.49d0b60822fb26cde02240008c1ba061@haiku-os.org>

#4825: BSoundPlayer segv
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Adek336         |       Owner:  marcusoverhagen
     Type:  bug             |      Status:  new            
 Priority:  normal          |   Milestone:  R1             
Component:  Kits/Media Kit  |     Version:  R1/Development 
Blockedby:                  |    Platform:  All            
 Blocking:                  |  
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
 {{{
 #include <Sound.h>
 #include <SoundPlayer.h>
 #include <Entry.h>


 void playsound(const char *path) {
    BSound *sound;
    BSoundPlayer player;
    entry_ref ref;
    BEntry entry(path, true);
    BSoundPlayer::play_id id;

    if (entry.InitCheck() == B_OK) {
       if (entry.GetRef(&ref) == B_OK) {
          sound = new BSound(&ref);
          if (sound->InitCheck() == B_OK) {
             player.Start();
             player.SetVolume(1.0);
             id = player.StartPlaying(sound);
             sound->ReleaseRef();
             player.WaitForSound(id);
          }
       }
    }
 }

 int main()
 {
     playsound("/boot/home/sample.wav");
     return 0;
 }

 }}}

 Put a wave file as /boot/home/sample.wav, compile and run.


 It either crashes or prints

 {{{
 ...
 WavReader::GetNextChunk: LAST BUFFER ERROR at time   1000000
 ...
 Abort
 ...
 }}}

 and hangs.

 Reproduced on Alpha 1, also on gcc4+2 hybrid r33542.

 The playsound function comes from the Be Book
 [http://www.haikudev.com/bebookpl/The%20Media%20Kit/SoundPlayer.html#BSoundPlayer]

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4825>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 21 21:47:41 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (v)
Date: Wed, 21 Oct 2009 19:47:41 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4827: Crash in pthread_create
In-Reply-To: <042.a9275adffc3db4b555a9a7483e98e6c2@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.a9275adffc3db4b555a9a7483e98e6c2@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.dafffd6089c76cbd1ff293aeb828a129@haiku-os.org>

#4827: Crash in pthread_create
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  kaliber       |       Owner:  nobody        
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/POSIX  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by v):

 Perhaps

 {{{
 if (*_attr == NULL)
   return EINVAL;
 else
   attr = *_attr;
 }}}

 is more like it. And looking at the error codes of the rest of the file

 {{{
 if (*_attr == NULL)
   return B_BAD_VALUE;
 else
   attr = *_attr;
 }}}

 would be more consistent.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4827#comment:2>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Comment(by v):

 Seems like a silly thing to do, calling pthread_detach() after
 pthread_join(), but if it's a valid action perhaps attached patch is an
 acceptable solution.[[BR]]
 I'd be inclined to return B_BAD_VALUE for a thread that has already been
 detached, but that doesn't agree with the testcase.[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 The patch has '''not''' been compiled or tested.[[BR]]
 I couldn't find any POSIX doc that agreed or disagreed with the testcase,
 but I haven't looked very hard.[[BR]]

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 22 08:41:48 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (cdr)
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 2009 06:41:48 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4433: PPC haiku-boot-cd-ppc broken on
 x86_64 Linux compiles.
In-Reply-To: <044.a392b1b3670d0a93f2d1683b4e93f7f7@haiku-os.org>
References: <044.a392b1b3670d0a93f2d1683b4e93f7f7@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <053.8dbe281dbfe1a14593a61ece4b436e8f@haiku-os.org>

#4433: PPC haiku-boot-cd-ppc broken on x86_64 Linux compiles.
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  kallisti5           |       Owner:  axeld        
     Type:  bug                 |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  System/Boot Loader  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  PowerPC      
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------

Comment(by cdr):

 I got the same problem when trying to build x86 Haiku on x86_64 Linux. The
 first thing I had to do to build the cross toolchain was to use linux32 to
 fool it into thinking it's building on i686 (well, libiberty's configure
 didn't detect x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu as a valid platform):
 $ linux32 ./configure --build-cross-tools ./buildtools/

 After that the toolchain built OK, but then when I tried to actually build
 any part of Haiku, it failed when trying to build libroot.so with exactly
 the same error as in the bug report. It looked like setversion has failed.

 I debugged setversion and I found out that the size of Elf32_Ehdr
 structure is 80 bytes instead of 52 bytes - classical portability issue.
 So I looked at the types in headers/os/support/SupportDefs.h and
 headers/[build/]os/support/SupportDefs.h and uint32 is defined as unsigned
 long and int32 is defined as long. 64-bit Linux follows LP64 convention
 meaning that long is 64-bit, so it means that [u]int32 is actually 64-bit
 in the cross-binaries (like e.g. setversion) used to build Haiku.

 To fix it [u]int32 has to be redefined as [unsigned]int. This fix will
 also be needed is Haiku will ever be ported to x86_64/amd64 arch. Fixing
 this will also trigger changes in BString::operator<< (duplicate int and
 int32) as well as in a couple of other places where string formatting is
 done.

 Please let me know if I can do anything to help to solve this. I can even
 provide a sample change set, but this seems easy to fix so far but will
 still probably require more testing.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4433#comment:5>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 22 09:05:34 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (tqh)
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 2009 07:05:34 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4762: Hang at boot with updated ACPI
	module
In-Reply-To: <044.06b7adc724a094dd1830044d2209c96b@haiku-os.org>
References: <044.06b7adc724a094dd1830044d2209c96b@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <053.cb9c7b49346269ad0a4c98b18dc8aac8@haiku-os.org>

#4762: Hang at boot with updated ACPI module
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  atomozero     |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/ACPI  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
Changes (by tqh):

 * cc: fredrik.holmqvist@? (added)


Comment:

 Hanging that late is probably not the ACPI impl itself (it did pass ACPI
 init and is in ACPI mode). It's most likely one of the ACPI drivers,
 probably ACPI Embedded Controller. Try removing it when booting with ACPI
 disabled and see if it boots to desktop.

 (ACPI init is done under the third icon)

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 22 09:50:26 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (axeld)
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 2009 07:50:26 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4433: PPC haiku-boot-cd-ppc broken on
 x86_64 Linux compiles.
In-Reply-To: <044.a392b1b3670d0a93f2d1683b4e93f7f7@haiku-os.org>
References: <044.a392b1b3670d0a93f2d1683b4e93f7f7@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <053.f070299846679d8e4b324cfad5cbf1a7@haiku-os.org>

#4433: PPC haiku-boot-cd-ppc broken on x86_64 Linux compiles.
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  kallisti5          |       Owner:  axeld        
     Type:  bug                |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  System/libroot.so  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------

Comment(by axeld):

 Yes, we're aware of that problem - BeOS defined [u]int32 as "long", so
 it's part of the ABI (function signatures look different if you would
 change this).

 For the GCC4 build we could change this now, though (causing all existing
 packages to be rebuilt), and for platforms other than x86 it should be
 changed right away, anyway.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4433#comment:7>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.
