From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 22 10:56:20 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 2009 08:56:20 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4830: "Expand New Applications" not always
	practical
Message-ID: <044.a0ba69828ae831585f248509974140b4@haiku-os.org>

#4830: "Expand New Applications" not always practical
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger             |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  enhancement           |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Deskbar  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                        |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                        |  
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 This is r33708.

 Even though the options "Show Application Expander" and "Expand New
 Applications" are activated, after boot-up the Tracker entry is always
 collapsed.[[BR]]
 The auto-launched LaunchPad, however, is expanded. This is because Tracker
 is started earlier than the Deskbar and thus isn't considered a "New
 Application".

 You can see the same behaviour, when you have a couple of running apps,
 all expanded, and then quit the Deskbar via ProcessController. Upon
 Deskbar restart, every app is collapsed.

 Now, does it really make sense to just "Expand *New* Applications" or
 would it be more practical to have the setting to just "Expand
 Applications"? I think the latter.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4830>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

#4828: Crash in pthread_detach (double free)
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  kaliber       |       Owner:  nobody        
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/POSIX  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by kaliber):

 According to specification
 http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/000095399/functions/pthread_detach.html
 function should return 0 instead of B_OK and EINVAL instead of
 B_BAD_VALUE.

--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  kaliber       |       Owner:  nobody        
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  System/POSIX  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by anevilyak):

 Replying to [comment:3 kaliber]:
 > According to specification
 http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/000095399/functions/pthread_detach.html
 function should return 0 instead of B_OK and EINVAL instead of
 B_BAD_VALUE.

 Which are precisely the values B_OK and B_BAD_VALUE map to.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 22 18:49:21 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 2009 16:49:21 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4832: Idea for a "GnomeDo" like app
	finder/launcher
Message-ID: <044.94c793bb15b293216dc5b628ed528f31@haiku-os.org>

#4832: Idea for a "GnomeDo" like app finder/launcher
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger     |       Owner:  nobody        
     Type:  enhancement   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Recently someone in the forums mentioned Gnome's "Do". This has been on my
 mind for a long time now. Finally, I found some time to do a mockup and
 write down how I could imagine it working.

 So, in my mind, a systemwide shortcut like OPT+spacebar opens this (at
 first empty) panel:

 [[Image(HaikuDo.png)]]

 You type in "disk" and a query looks for all applications with "disk" in
 their name. The query will only start after at least three letters are
 entered and is updated in realtime. The list below the search box fills
 with the results: icon, name, path and short description. Alphabetically
 all apps starting with "disk" are listed, then all with "disk" anywhere in
 their names.

 The panel size could automatically adjust within sane proportions to avoid
 scrolling bars if possible.

 The panel could be intelligent and learn what app you've started most
 often when entering a particular string and automatically pre-select that
 entry.

 CursorUp/Down moves the app-selection.[[BR]]
 Return leaves the panel and starts the app.[[BR]]
 Esc aborts.
 Any other key (CursorLeft/Right, backspace, del or any letter) affects the
 search box so you can quickly refine or correct a search.

 With this alone, Deskbar's Application/Demos/Desktop Applets/Preference
 menu, would become obsolete (for me). I would be very thrilled if somebody
 was interested in implementing this!

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4832>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 23 01:18:12 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (v)
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 2009 23:18:12 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3945: getaddrinfo() issue
In-Reply-To: <042.a8d241555d8a2f12a3dc7f5681aacb76@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.a8d241555d8a2f12a3dc7f5681aacb76@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.0adccc1c463dc1598b54ab24fb507950@haiku-os.org>

#3945: getaddrinfo() issue
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  kaliber           |       Owner:  axeld        
     Type:  bug               |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Kits/Network Kit  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                    |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                    |  
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------

Comment(by v):

 One place it can be found
 [http://gitweb.samba.org/?p=samba.git;a=blob;f=source3/libsmb/namequery.c;h=930f0a54f4cffab1986736fa9aa3f9046229d856;hb=HEAD#l1204
 is in source3/libsmb/namequery.c], but there are more.

 getaddrinfo() in the Haiku source [http://dev.haiku-
 os.org/browser/haiku/trunk/src/kits/network/dns/irs/getaddrinfo.c?annotate=blame#L518
 already checks] for the presence of AI_ADDRCONFIG, so perhaps adding
 AI_ADDRCONFIG to the AI_MASK definition is enough for the mentioned samba
 issue.

 BTW,
 [http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/functions/getaddrinfo.html
 this getaddrinfo spec] suggests a few more flags: AI_NUMERICSERV,
 AI_V4MAPPED and AI_ALL

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3945#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 23 12:01:29 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (mmlr)
Date: Fri, 23 Oct 2009 10:01:29 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4835: r33626 causes interrupt trouble
In-Reply-To: <041.49719af0e1590ce05dd17b6b4c3c8e4c@haiku-os.org>
References: <041.49719af0e1590ce05dd17b6b4c3c8e4c@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <050.9dd0106319d239edff62c37163170bf5@haiku-os.org>

#4835: r33626 causes interrupt trouble
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  brecht        |       Owner:  marcusoverhagen
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new            
 Priority:  high          |   Milestone:  R1             
Component:  Drivers/Disk  |     Version:  R1/alpha1      
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All            
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by mmlr):

 Since enabling interrupts is now done earlier, i.e. before device
 selection and writing the command, the devices might just fire interrupts
 on selection/writing the command which we don't "expect" yet. We do
 unconditionally read the status register to acknowledge in this case
 though to avoid generating interrupt storms. Still it could explain the
 output, as we also return B_UNHANDLED_INTERRUPT in such a case because we
 have no way of figuring out if it was our interrupt.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4835#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 23 15:19:36 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (tangobravo)
Date: Fri, 23 Oct 2009 13:19:36 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4836: CPU spikes in media_addon_server
Message-ID: <045.516bc2865d7ea16799f2d62f0d14f0c9@haiku-os.org>

#4836: CPU spikes in media_addon_server
------------------------+---------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  tangobravo  |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug         |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal      |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  - General   |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:              |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:              |  
------------------------+---------------------------------------------------
 My laptop gives occasional (a bit random, but usually 2 or 3 per minute)
 100% CPU spikes in threads within the media_addon_server, often the "Yeah
 baby, very shagadelic" but sometimes the "Intel HD Audio control" thread.
 Happens with both HDA driver, and OSS (with hda moved to desktop). The
 spike lasts for a couple of seconds, and as these are real-time priority
 threads, seem to freeze the entire system.

 Attached an output from scheduling_recorder showing the event. Also a
 syslog and listdev.

 Not sure if it's related - but it also seems to freeze hard after about 20

 update (terminal cursor flashes, for example), but no mouse/keyboard input
 is accepted and I can't enter KDL.

 the freezes but just seems to shift it to different threads. Could this
 point to an interupt problem? Doing and int in KDL shows IRQ 10 shared by
 oss, ata * 2, ehci, uhci * 5 and marvel_yukon. It also says handled 37599,
 unhandled 2663723.

 Other stuff: USB doesn't work on this laptop. Sound works with OSS, not
 with the native hda driver, although it does show up in media prefs.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 23 16:09:26 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Meanwhile)
Date: Fri, 23 Oct 2009 14:09:26 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4837: limited stroke width
Message-ID: <044.8b90fc98b8d2cff4559056048f378a69@haiku-os.org>

#4837: limited stroke width
---------------------------------------+------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Meanwhile                  |       Owner:  stippi   
     Type:  bug                        |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal                     |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Applications/Icon-O-Matic  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                             |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                             |  
---------------------------------------+------------------------------------
 Under properties, the width of a stroke can be set in more precise values
 than just round numbers. [[BR]]
 When -for example- changing a shape's width from 1.00 to 1.50, the
 stroke's thickening is clearly visible in I-O-M's preview windows.[[BR]]
 So, one would expect this new shape to be saved just like it appears
 there, but this is not the case. After saving, the new shape with a 1.50
 wide stroke is identical to its original shape with a 1.00 wide stroke.
 [[BR]]
 This happens with any value between round numbers; e.g. 1.95 looks just
 like 1.00 and 1.50 (after saving).

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4837>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 23 21:02:47 2009

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4485: change our vmware network type from
 'bridged' to 'nat'
In-Reply-To: <040.ab56fb828ac8c13097ec150ddc5f81da@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.ab56fb828ac8c13097ec150ddc5f81da@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.fffaa06d1e845656f7a4c3e6bea06a4a@haiku-os.org>

#4485: change our vmware network type from 'bridged' to 'nat'
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  luroh               |       Owner:  axeld        
     Type:  enhancement         |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Network & Internet  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------

Comment(by luroh):

 We included NAT'ed mode in the vmx file distributed along with the R1/A1
 release and it seems to have been a good choice; I haven't heard of a
 single vmware network issue. I propose we incorporate this change in our
 vmx file in the repo (trunk/3rdparty/vmware/).

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4485#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Hello,

 I have built P7zip for GCC4 on r33573 of Haiku.

 Below is a link to the zip file, including the .OptionalPackageDescription
 file:

 http://haiku-ports.de/packages/app-
 arch/p7zip/p7zip-9.04-x86-gcc4-2009-10-24.zip

 It will need to be moved to http://haiku-files.org/files/optional-
 packages/ in order for the attached patch to work.  There is already a
 p7zip 9.04 optional package I did back in July that is on the haiku-
 files.org server, but I figured it'd make sense to do a build on a current
 (post-alpha) version of Haiku.

---------------------------------------+------------------------------------
 r33753 gcc4+2 hybrid

 Disable VirtualMemory, reboot, disk space still used by swap. Go to
 VirtualMemory preferences ; note that the size slider is not disabled.
 Anyhow, moving the slider to 1 MiB does not free up memory either.
 /boot/var/swap is still 2 GiB.

 Removing the file frees up memory and doesn't introduce any problems or
 crashes.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Oct 24 18:23:55 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (jprostko)
Date: Sat, 24 Oct 2009 16:23:55 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4842: [patch] P7zip optional package for

In-Reply-To: <043.b3c7b1ab96b9039a8ce7be4f3126ce7c@haiku-os.org>

Message-ID: <052.66576017e7182f7340f16bf37b6b8977@haiku-os.org>

#4842: [patch] P7zip optional package for GCC4
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  jprostko      |       Owner:  bonefish      
     Type:  enhancement   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Build System  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by jprostko):

 Replying to [comment:1 korli]:
 > Sorry, but what's the need for this gcc4 build ?
 > There is the gcc2 build which is also fine for gcc4 haiku builds.
 > http://haiku-files.org/files/optional-
 packages/p7zip-9.04-r1a1-x86-gcc2-2009-08-30.zip

 Well, seeing as there is C++ code and the GCC2 version is therefore linked
 against libstdcc++.r4.so instead of libstdc++.so, it won't work on a
 strictly GCC4 build of Haiku.  I suppose I didn't really notice either
 until I tried making a purely GCC4 build of Haiku lately, only to have
 P7zip not work.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4842#comment:2>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Sat Oct 24 18:33:08 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (jprostko)
Date: Sat, 24 Oct 2009 16:33:08 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4842: [patch] P7zip optional package for
	GCC4
In-Reply-To: <043.b3c7b1ab96b9039a8ce7be4f3126ce7c@haiku-os.org>
References: <043.b3c7b1ab96b9039a8ce7be4f3126ce7c@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <052.f725ad869216b14995b51f85ede49cb8@haiku-os.org>

#4842: [patch] P7zip optional package for GCC4
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  jprostko      |       Owner:  bonefish      
     Type:  enhancement   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Build System  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by jprostko):

 Replying to [comment:2 jprostko]:

 > Well, seeing as there is C++ code and the GCC2 version is therefore
 linked against libstdcc++.r4.so instead of libstdc++.so, it won't work on
 a strictly GCC4 build of Haiku.  I suppose I didn't really notice either
 until I tried making a purely GCC4 build of Haiku lately, only to have
 P7zip not work.
 >
 >

 Sorry to reply to myself, but I hit reply a little prematurely without
 thinking through my response completely.  The patch also addressed the
 fact that you aren't given a P7zip at all if you do a pure GCC4 build.
 You would then have to download one from haiku-files.org...assuming you
 know about it.  If you happened to download one of the GCC2 versions
 there, it wouldn't work at all, complaining about a missing
 libstdc++.r4.so.  If you downloaded the optional package I made for GCC4
 back in July from there though, it would work as desired.  I just don't
 see the need to jump through hoops like that for somebody who isn't aware
 of those facts.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4842#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 scroll bar being active at the default window sizing when viewing the
 partition list.

 of the column without collapsing. Documented in comment:ticket:3036:7

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 02:23:40 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (augiedoggie)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 01:23:40 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4846: thread deadlock in BMenuField
Message-ID: <046.ab556d26a7d8619f61d7cbf2cd55b09f@haiku-os.org>

#4846: thread deadlock in BMenuField
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  augiedoggie         |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug                 |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Kits/Interface Kit  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 While attempting to diagnose a problem in the BeAE program, I came across
 some odd behavior within BMenuField.  The problem only occurs, on average,
 around 1 out of every 5 tries.  Basically you have a BMenuItem attached to
 a BMenuField, which when selected, destroys the BMenuField object.  The
 BMenuField destructor then gets stuck in wait_for_thread() waiting for the
 mouse tracking thread to die.  I hope I've made that clear :)


 I'm attaching some sample code which might explain it better.  I assume
 that this code and the stuff from BeAE worked on BeOS, but, I no longer
 have it installed to test.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4846>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 03:30:56 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Pete)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 02:30:56 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4847: Wacom Intuos not handled
Message-ID: <039.e9276e61ad5064936bf6a59eaade5d50@haiku-os.org>

#4847: Wacom Intuos not handled
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Pete                   |       Owner:  korli    
     Type:  bug                    |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal                 |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Add-Ons/Input Methods  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                         |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 I found that my (original) Intuos 6x8 USB didn't function properly under
 Haiku (though it has always worked fine with Stippi et al's code in BeOS).
 Looking at the source I saw that the pen-contact (Button 1) detection had
 changed from the earlier code, and no longer matched the Intuos protocol.

 While fixing this, I did some reverse engineering, and found out how the
 Eraser function is signalled.  (This was never implemented in the code.)

 So I made a patch (attached) that gives my tablet full function.  I think
 it should be compatible with the other models handled by the same code,
 but of course this needs to be checked.

 There are a couple of fiddle-factors that are right for my tablet (contact
 detection and proximity), but I don't know if there's likely to be any
 problem with them for others.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4847>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 05:44:58 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (hiron)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 04:44:58 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4848: raw_char field in B_KEY_DOWN message
 when using input method
Message-ID: <040.e755ae94334f4f3bed2ca5b23b7c1976@haiku-os.org>

#4848: raw_char field in B_KEY_DOWN message when using input method
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  hiron      |       Owner:  nobody        
     Type:  bug        |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal     |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  - General  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:             |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:             |  
-----------------------+----------------------------------------------------
 In pe editor, when I input Japanese characters by IM (input method), pe
 says "An OS error occurred: Name not found" and no characters are
 displayed.
 This is because pe checks the existance of "raw_char" field in a
 B_KEY_DOWN message (in PText::KeyDown()):
 {{{
 #!cpp
 FailOSErr(Looper()->CurrentMessage()->FindInt32("raw_char", &ch));
 }}}

 On BeOS R5, I got 0x0a as "raw_char" value in B_KEY_DOWN message.
 I don't know why 0x0a is used but I never got other value on inputting
 text by IM.

 On Haiku, BottomlineWindow for non-input-method-aware views doesn't put
 "raw_char" field in B_KEY_DOWN message.
 I tried to put it (as attached patch) and pe worked well this time.

 Is this behavior intended one? : there may not be "raw_char" field in
 B_KEY_DOWN message.
 If so, it's not a Haiku's bug but a pe's.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4848>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 10:12:37 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (matjako)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 09:12:37 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4849: BSlider - broken BArchivable

Message-ID: <042.9f845d1cc40db80f97f34c1ac1c8cde3@haiku-os.org>

#4849: BSlider - broken BArchivable implementation
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  matjako             |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug                 |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Kits/Interface Kit  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Unlike with other BView classes, archiving a BSlider object and
 instantiating it does not create a valid BView.
 When a previously Archive()'d BSlider is constructed from the resulting
 message (archive) and added to a view, nothing happens (compared to say,
 BButton).

 Observed in rev33728.

 STEPS TO REPRODUCE:

 See attachment. Single file, compile with: gcc test-barchivable.cpp -lroot
 -lbe

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 10:52:53 2009

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4850: Moving files via spring-folder copies
	instead
Message-ID: <044.7e190ecffe1f388b9e63de1123842b06@haiku-os.org>

#4850: Moving files via spring-folder copies instead
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger             |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Tracker  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                        |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                        |  
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 This is r33755.

 Grab a file from one partition and drag&hover it over a folder from a
 second partition. After a (much too long...) while, the "spring-folder"
 navigation is activated and you can drill down the folder hierarchy. When
 you release the mouse button at your destination, the grabbed file is
 *moved*.

 When drag&dropping a file to another partition, it's normally *copied*,
 however. This does work as expected, when simply drag&dropping it on some
 folder or an open window. Only the spring-folder-drill-down method behaves
 differently.

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 16:19:53 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (jprostko)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 15:19:53 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4842: [patch] P7zip optional package for
	GCC4
In-Reply-To: <043.b3c7b1ab96b9039a8ce7be4f3126ce7c@haiku-os.org>
References: <043.b3c7b1ab96b9039a8ce7be4f3126ce7c@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <052.4d1c389f013cfbf585da0d74fd347045@haiku-os.org>

#4842: [patch] P7zip optional package for GCC4
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  jprostko      |       Owner:  bonefish      
     Type:  enhancement   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Build System  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by jprostko):

 Replying to [comment:6 korli]:
 > Would it be possible to check if the GCC2 package works as is on a GCC4
 Haiku.
 > One package should fit both.

 Just checked it, and like I expected, got the following:

 ~> 7za
 runtime_loader: Cannot open file libstdc++.r4.so: No such file or
 directory

 Basically, the GCC2 package will work on a pure or hybrid GCC2 build, as
 well as a GCC4 hybrid build, but not work on a pure GCC4 build.  The GCC4
 package will work on a pure or hybrid GCC4 build, as well as a GCC2 hybrid
 build, but not work on a pure GCC2 build.  In other words, the pure GCC
 builds don't have the other GCC's C++ libraries available.

 The GCC4 build of p7zip requires libroot.so and libstdc++.so , whereas the
 GCC2 build requires libroot.so and libstdc++.r4.so .  If this were curl or
 something we were compiling that only had C code, then yeah, it'd work
 just fine for all GCC variant builds since there were no ABI changes.
 Since there is C++ code involved, however, it simply won't work that way.

 If the plan is to do away with supporting of building GCC4-only builds in
 the future (and/or GCC2-only builds for that matter), then yeah, we could
 tidy up OptionalPackages quite a bit by building GCC2 versions of most
 packages, and building GCC4 packages only when needed.  I kind of don't
 think that is in the pipeline or anything as far as I know though.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4842#comment:7>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 18:17:03 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 17:17:03 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4851: Remove use of attributes/queries for
	signature/status
Message-ID: <044.83b9e7213c43978624889a74c19756f5@haiku-os.org>

#4851: Remove use of attributes/queries for signature/status
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger          |       Owner:  bga           
     Type:  enhancement        |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Mail  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 This is r33755.

 At the moment Mail finds its signatures (stored by default in
 ~/config/settings/Mail/signatures) with a query for their _signature
 attribute.[[BR]]
 Custom statuses(sp?) (stored by default in ~/config/settings/Mail/status)
 are of some binary format and have a _status attribute.

 The use of attributes and queries for this is not very sensible. For once,
 those attributes have to be indexed, which they are at Mail's first start-
 up. Still, this can complicate restoring backups in a newly installed
 system.

 Much easier for managing sigs and statuses is to use simple text files.
 File name is the sig-title the contents the sig-contents. The status is
 set by its file name alone.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4851>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 19:09:27 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (tqh)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 18:09:27 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4762: Hang at boot with updated ACPI
	module
In-Reply-To: <044.06b7adc724a094dd1830044d2209c96b@haiku-os.org>
References: <044.06b7adc724a094dd1830044d2209c96b@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <053.5d48f1d2e6ae58c028ec0e3c86e796c3@haiku-os.org>

#4762: Hang at boot with updated ACPI module
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  atomozero     |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug           |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/ACPI  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                |  
--------------------------+-------------------------------------------------

Comment(by tqh):

 I think the attached patch should fix this as I had, and was working on
 tracking the same issue on my laptop. For me it turned out that the global
 locking code was broken, and all my systems can now fully run under ACPI.

 (Some additional code is in the patch, but IMO that should be updated as
 well.)
 FreeBSD impl can be viewed here:
 http://fxr.watson.org/fxr/source/dev/acpica/Osd/OsdSynch.c#L581

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 19:28:06 2009

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4852: bug ticket #3663
Message-ID: <046.43d79b629e1871fbd7c69b5b174d4c08@haiku-os.org>

#4852: bug ticket #3663
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  haikuhacker  |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug          |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal       |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  - General    |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:               |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:               |  
-------------------------+--------------------------------------------------
 [http://www.haiku-os.org/community/forum/bug_ticket_3663]

 This ticket states:

 Haiku fails to boot. The booting process goes fine, until the desktop is
 supposed to appear, but only the blue background appears and the mouse is
 frozen, the system can't even be rebooted with ctrl-alt-del.

 I am have no clue, whether this is related to the recent directory changes
 or not. The last revision, which I'm sure that it worked was r29805.

 This is a fresh image with no prior file lying around, which might cause
 trouble.

 Failing revision is r29881.

 Changed 7 months ago by mmlr ?

 Most likely it is a conflict between the hda driver and OSS. The hda
 driver has been added to the default image and will conflict with OSS if
 you have the corresponding optional package installed. Please remove
 either the hda or the OSS driver from your installation in that case.
 Changed 7 months ago by rossi ?

 Yeah, figured that one out and are happy again ;) feel free to close this
 bug as invalid.
 Changed 7 months ago by stippi ?

 * status changed from new to closed
 * resolution set to invalid

 Ok, thanks for the feedback!

 I am having difficulty getting sound to work with the HDA driver and have
 submitted a bug #4838 about it. In the mean time I installed a
 Soundblaster Live sound card in my machine turning off the onboard audio
 option in the bios setup. Then I did a fresh (formatted new partition)
 installation of Haiku Alpha 1 from the live cd without any optional
 packages and got the same results as above on the first boot.

 I'm guessing that the installation detected my Soundblaster card and
 provided OSS automatically along with the embedded HDA driver. So I tried
 removing the HDA driver from /boot/system/add-
 ons/kernel/drivers/dev/audio/hmulti and /boot/system/add-
 ons/kernel/drivers/bin. This doesn't fix the problem for me like it did
 for stippi, using r29881.

 My question is does the kernel always look for the HDA driver because its
 been added to the default image, even after removing the actual HDA files
 and will I ever be able to use my Soundblaster Live in Haiku?

--

Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>

From trac at haiku-os.org  Sun Oct 25 23:42:16 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (Cytor)
Date: Sun, 25 Oct 2009 22:42:16 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4503: Bootman won't install on a mixed
 IDE and AHCI system
In-Reply-To: <043.c693409540f669253d9b5a5a9e08b500@haiku-os.org>
References: <043.c693409540f669253d9b5a5a9e08b500@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <052.b29efd0e4299179897b033932d5c72c3@haiku-os.org>

#4503: Bootman won't install on a mixed IDE and AHCI system
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  ddewbofh            |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug                 |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/Boot Loader  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
Changes (by Cytor):

 * cc: pascal.penners@? (added)


Comment:

 Same problem for me. Two hard drives on ICH8-M AHCI, one optical drive on
 ICH8-M ATA. Also tried creating partitions with parted, but no success.

 Workaround: temporarily setting the controller mode from AHCI to IDE (if
 you can); then BootMan is able to properly install. After that, reboot and
 set the mode back to AHCI. BootMan will work and boot the system just
 fine. This worked for me.
 So maybe this is just an issue with the BootMan installer and not with the
 actual bootloader itself?

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4503#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Oct 26 01:19:36 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (v)
Date: Mon, 26 Oct 2009 00:19:36 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4853: non-alphanumeric characters are shown
 as HTML escape sequences
Message-ID: <036.1f71214093c375c256efdb291a0a3f92@haiku-os.org>

#4853: non-alphanumeric characters are shown as HTML escape sequences
---------------------+------------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  v        |       Owner:  haiku-web     
     Type:  bug      |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal   |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Website  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:           |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:           |  
---------------------+------------------------------------------------------
 http://www.haiku-
 os.org/documents/dev/driver_development_presentation_waltercon_2006
 [[BR]]
 Instead of the non-alphanumeric characters the HTML escape sequences for
 them are _shown_.[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 I'd guess this isn't the only page on which this occurs, so maybe this can
 be solved without awaiting a report for each page.[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 I'll go into specifics now:[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 under heading "1. Device File System"[[BR]]
 under heading "For development:"[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 in the sentence[[BR]]
 ''use rescan &lt;driver name&gt; to make sure the system reloads your
 driver after a recompilation''[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 should be '''<driver name>''' instead of '''&lt;driver name&gt;''' [[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 under heading "2. Modules"[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 in the first code block
 {{{
         module_info *modules[] = {
                 (module_info *)&amp;scsi_for_sim_module,
                 (module_info *)&amp;scsi_bus_module,
                 (module_info *)&amp;scsi_device_module,
                 (module_info *)&amp;scsi_bus_raw_module,
                 NULL
         };
 }}}
 should be
 {{{
         module_info *modules[] = {
                 (module_info *)&scsi_for_sim_module,
                 (module_info *)&scsi_bus_module,
                 (module_info *)&scsi_device_module,
                 (module_info *)&scsi_bus_raw_module,
                 NULL
         };
 }}}
 in the second code block[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 the lines
 {{{
                 (module_info **)&amp;gManager);
         if (status &lt; B_OK) {
 }}}
 should be
 {{{
                 (module_info **)&gManager);
         if (status < B_OK) {
 }}}

 in the third code block[[BR]]
 the lines
 {{{
                 {B_DEVICE_MANAGER_MODULE_NAME, (module_info
 **)&amp;gManager},
                 {LOCKED_POOL_MODULE_NAME, (module_info
 **)&amp;gLockedPool},
 }}}

 should be
 {{{
                 {B_DEVICE_MANAGER_MODULE_NAME, (module_info **)&gManager},
                 {LOCKED_POOL_MODULE_NAME, (module_info **)&gLockedPool},
 }}}

 under heading "4. Interrupts"[[BR]]
 [[BR]]
 the first code block
 {{{
 status = install_io_interrupt_handler(info.pci-&gt;u.h0.interrupt_line,
                 &amp;my_interrupt_handler, (void *)&amp;info, 0);
 }}}

 should probably be

 {{{
 status = install_io_interrupt_handler(info.pci->u.h0.interrupt_line,
                 &my_interrupt_handler, (void *)&info, 0);}}}

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4853>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  michaelvoliveira  |       Owner:  stippi        
     Type:  bug               |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1

 Blocking:                    |

 I can create, let's say /usr folder into / directory, but I can't copy any
 files into my new folder. When I close the tracker window and reopen usr
 folder is invisible. typing on the address navigator or terminal puts me
 into it.

 I know that /boot/common folder is utilized to handle everything but I
 think that is an user choice to use in your PC.

 But with this limitation, several apps and games that use /usr/local from
 others unixes will not run on Haiku!

 I could continue building with --configure=/boot/common and the make file
 installs on shared folder, bin folder, etc. but some apps with data files
 refuses to accept.

 For exemple: OpenArena, DreamChess don't run *is not a SDL problem!!* how
 was discussed in the ML. Several others apps that myself ported failed to
 load your resources. I had many troubles with this (un)feature! and I bet
 that many other users will be.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Oct 26 07:36:19 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (siarzhuk)

Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4854: impossible manage folders in "/"
	directory
In-Reply-To: <051.affd8f1f254efd0450df3bb104800f35@haiku-os.org>

Message-ID: <060.772cd4e10583b5cd5f8af9af774a04f2@haiku-os.org>

#4854: impossible manage folders in "/" directory
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  michaelvoliveira  |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug               |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  File Systems/BFS  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                    |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                    |  
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------

Comment(by siarzhuk):

 Note that "/" is a virtual, "rootfs" filesystem. To utilize things you
 want - you have to use symbolic links to real folders, but AFAIK using of
 --prefix=/boot/common is a mandatory option for configure during porting
 applications to Haiku OS.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4854#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Oct 26 17:56:31 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Mon, 26 Oct 2009 16:56:31 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4494: [Terminal] some default color
 settings are hard to read
In-Reply-To: <042.c9e3ed5536a611fb0ba49f4faf2692f3@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.c9e3ed5536a611fb0ba49f4faf2692f3@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.7acb69441fd21ea4d2c935e4d33c6a43@haiku-os.org>

#4494: [Terminal] some default color settings are hard to read
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  scottmc                |       Owner:  jackburton
     Type:  bug                    |      Status:  new       
 Priority:  normal                 |   Milestone:  R1        
Component:  Applications/Terminal  |     Version:  R1/alpha1 
Blockedby:                         |    Platform:  All       
 Blocking:                         |  
-----------------------------------+----------------------------------------

Comment(by humdinger):

 {{{
 dircolors -p > /boot/system/etc/.dircolors
 }}}

 produces a list of the used default colors. I have looked for blue-on-
 green (34;42) which was only found for STICKY_OTHER_WRITABLE and changed
 that to black-on-green (30;42).

 Putting
 {{{
 eval `dircolors -b /boot/system/etc/.dircolors`
 }}}

 into /boot/system/etc/profile should load these new color on every
 Terminal start.
 I couldn't test, because I couldn't find anything that was blue-on-green
 to begin with.
 I attached the slightly altered .dircolors. Maybe someone has another itch
 to scratch and modifies a few more entries before committing it together
 with the changes to the profile.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4494#comment:6>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

Comment(by tqh):

 The check in AcpiOsWritable should probably be:

 {{{
         return (info.protection & B_READ_AREA) &&
                         (info.protection & B_WRITE_AREA) &&
                         (pointer + length) <= (info.address +
 info.ram_size);
 }}}

From trac at haiku-os.org  Mon Oct 26 19:54:26 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (humdinger)
Date: Mon, 26 Oct 2009 18:54:26 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4857: Force Identify only works when holding
	SHIFT
Message-ID: <044.bde8fd08d887cf5fa5bf93fa19de75ac@haiku-os.org>

#4857: Force Identify only works when holding SHIFT
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 Reporter:  humdinger             |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  bug                   |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Applications/Tracker  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                        |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                        |  
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
 This is r33755.

 If you right-click a file while holding down SHIFT, the context menu shows
 slightly different commands. Among them "Force Identify" for correcting
 wrongly set filetypes.

 "Force Identify" only works when you hold down SHIFT while invoking the
 menu item.

 It should've been enough to hold SHIFT while right-clicking for the
 context menu to make the command "Force Identify" available. Selecting
 "Force Identify" from it should then work without holding SHIFT.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4857>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 we must fix it in BPathMonitor, not here.

Comment(by mmu_man):

 Sorry but I don't agree with the values returned by
 sched_get_priority_*()...
 see:
 http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/007908775/xsh/sched.h.html
 http://www.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/007908775/xsh/sched_get_priority_min.html
 IMO they should only be those part of the scheduling class (1-99 for
 other, 100-120 for FIFO, and btw is RR support mandatory ? as for now the
 BeOS classes don't include anything alike).

#4762: Hang at boot with updated ACPI module
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  atomozero     |       Owner:  nobody   
      Type:  bug           |      Status:  closed   
  Priority:  normal        |   Milestone:  R1       
 Component:  Drivers/ACPI  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Resolution:  fixed         |   Blockedby:           
  Platform:  All           |    Blocking:           
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by axeld):

 Replying to [comment:12 tqh]:
 > The check in AcpiOsWritable should probably be:
 >
 > {{{
 >       return (info.protection & B_READ_AREA) &&
 >                       (info.protection & B_WRITE_AREA) &&
 >                       (pointer + length) <= (info.address +
 info.ram_size);
 > }}}

 Besides the coding style issues, I'm not sure if that's what you mean.
 B_READ_AREA means readable from '''userland'''. Likewise, B_WRITE_AREA
 means writable from userland as well.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4762#comment:19>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>

Comment(by axeld):

 Replying to [comment:5 mmu_man]:
 > IMO they should only be those part of the scheduling class (1-99 for
 other, 100-120 for FIFO, and btw is RR support mandatory ? as for now the
 BeOS classes don't include anything alike).

 What we have is more or less RR (round-robin). Anyway, I wouldn't use real
 time priorities unless the code that uses this class is actually aware of
 that - it isn't really documented that way. This would require a bit more
 investigation.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 27 14:33:24 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (axeld)
Date: Tue, 27 Oct 2009 13:33:24 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4859: Sub-menus should keep the opening
 direction of their parents
Message-ID: <040.80f3e00f644bfca68abd6920c858e811@haiku-os.org>

#4859: Sub-menus should keep the opening direction of their parents
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  axeld               |       Owner:  axeld         
     Type:  enhancement         |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Kits/Interface Kit  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                      |    Platform:  All           
 Blocking:                      |  
--------------------------------+-------------------------------------------
 When opening a sub-menu, it should open in the same direction as its
 parent did.

 For example, if the Deskbar is in the top right corner, the first level
 menus all open to the left, as there is no space on the usual right side.
 However, the sub-menus sometimes open on the left, sometimes on the right,
 depending on their width. This is very confusing; the menus shouldn't
 change their opening direction.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4859>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 27 20:04:16 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (tqh)
Date: Tue, 27 Oct 2009 19:04:16 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #3961: vm_page_fault on less -f
	/dev/acpi/namespace exit
In-Reply-To: <051.2fd0bec6a6399d1ff9dc47d48272a477@haiku-os.org>
References: <051.2fd0bec6a6399d1ff9dc47d48272a477@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <060.a88ccfe66877f477fc2e4f0d95e9212d@haiku-os.org>

#3961: vm_page_fault on less -f /dev/acpi/namespace exit
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  michael.weirauch  |       Owner:  axeld        
     Type:  bug               |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal            |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  System            |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                    |    Platform:  x86          
 Blocking:                    |  
------------------------------+---------------------------------------------

Comment(by tqh):

 This is a driver issue. The code currently 'kill_thread' and then destroy
 the common ring_buffer. The thread used the Monthy Python phrase "I'm not
 dead yet" and tried to lock the ring_buffer anyway. (Btw, kill_thread is
 just supposed to signal the thread right, otherwise it's a bug in
 kill_thread)

 Switched it around to
 * delete the ring_buffers semaphore to signal it's time to end
 * graceful exit in the thread upon deletion of the sem
 * waiting for thread to die before cleanup

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/3961#comment:5>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 You might want to add a space before the asterisk, as that will trigger
 Trac's list mode.

 other than waking them up when they are sleeping/suspended.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Tue Oct 27 21:44:14 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (rudolfc)
Date: Tue, 27 Oct 2009 20:44:14 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4750: [ Matrox driver ] DVI
 detection/routing problem (DVI port doesn't work correctly)
In-Reply-To: <044.6baacb33d299562f9c00d578be45e8bc@haiku-os.org>
References: <044.6baacb33d299562f9c00d578be45e8bc@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <053.259540c382f53b90a31d38b16bec6d3c@haiku-os.org>

#4750: [ Matrox driver ] DVI detection/routing problem (DVI port doesn't work
correctly)
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------
 Reporter:  starsseed                |       Owner:  rudolfc       
     Type:  bug                      |      Status:  new           
 Priority:  normal                   |   Milestone:  R1            
Component:  Drivers/Graphics/Matrox  |     Version:  R1/Development
Blockedby:                           |    Platform:  x86           
 Blocking:                           |  
-------------------------------------+--------------------------------------

Comment(by rudolfc):

 Hi,

 I updated the exported modelist in r33797. Please see if 1920x1080 works
 OK now (over here it does, tested on a G450 VGA connector :-)

 This G450 is here since begeistert, and I see the DVI connector being
 shut-off even if I don't use the other connector. I'll test some more
 later on.

 The G450 I am testing is a PCI card, which is even reasonably fluent in
 firefox use and  outputting a HDTV trailer using bitmap mode works (though
 dropping frames due to bandwidth limits on the PCI bus).

 Note that overlay only works upto DVD resolution (I think it adheres to
 doc specs, but I'll try to find those docs back and check).

 Please be adviced that the matrox driver doesn't contain DDC/EDID code yet
 so all modes supported by the driver are exported, even if the monitor
 can't display it.

 Bye!

 Rudolf.



 Bye!

 Rudolf.

--

New description:

 This is a general ticket to track progress on internationalization. It
 only track the sourcecode and jamfiles part, not the availability of
 languages (this probably belongs outside of tracker)


 == Done ==
  * Appearance preflet (uses BColorControl which features untranslated
 "Red:", "Green:" and "Blue:")
  * Bluetooth preflet
  * CPU Frequency preflet
  * Fonts preflet
  * Keymap preflet
  * Locale preflet
  * Media preflet

 == Skipped ==
  * Background preflet : needs to use layout kit
  * DataTranslation preflet : layout kit
  * Devices preflet : layout kit
  * Dial-up networking preflet : layout kit
  * FileTypes preflet : layout kit
  * Joystick preflet : layout kit
  * Keyboard preflet : layout kit
  * Mail preflet : layout kit

 == Not done ==
  * Everything else for now.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 28 01:28:16 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (umccullough)
Date: Wed, 28 Oct 2009 00:28:16 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4751: network with 8169 driver
In-Reply-To: <040.b8ed9934219f9f136a4b7b22150cf3bc@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.b8ed9934219f9f136a4b7b22150cf3bc@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.764ff67d06be15b528faf452f91b591a@haiku-os.org>

#4751: network with 8169 driver
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  ikoli            |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/Network  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------

Comment(by umccullough):

 Replying to [comment:8 ikoli]:
 > 1. I can ping my gateway.

 Good. That basically confirms that the driver and hardware is working
 then.

 > 2.I tried several nameservers (few old and few new) from my ISP and none
 of them works.After I added them and click apply I get message from
 neworkstatus '''no link.'''I even tried OpenDNS and I was not able to ping
 them.My nameserver of choice was one I use in Ubuntu right now I that one
 also doesn?t work.I can ping OpenDNS and some nameservers from my ISP from
 Ubuntu without problem.My imagination stop here.Any other suggestions or
 ideas?

 If you can't even ping the nameservers by IP, then it sounds like it's not
 a DNS issue at all, but rather a routing issue.

 I didn't see any output from "route print" posted here, so it's hard to
 determine if something had gotten screwed up there or not.

 You can probably ignore the link state issue, IIRC, many of the ported
 FreeBSD drives don't report their linkstate such that the network status
 app can display it. I think that's a known issue, but feel free to correct
 me if I'm wrong.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4751#comment:12>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

---------------------------------+------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  Pete                 |       Owner:  phoudoin     
     Type:  bug                  |      Status:  assigned     
 Priority:  normal               |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Servers/midi_server  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                       |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                       |  
---------------------------------+------------------------------------------

Comment(by Pete):

 Replying to [comment:43 phoudoin]:
 > Patch applied in r33782.
 > I did some minor changes in midi_server part: I've kept the
 directory/symlink checks in !_AddDevice() and to not check path/name
 consistency in B_ENTRY_CREATED notification, as if it's a necessary hack
 we must fix it in BPathMonitor, not here.
 Yes, I slightly stand corrected...  On reflection, the check for a
 directory ''will'' be needed when BPathMonitor is fixed (as it should be)
 because it will then correctly announce the creation of the directory
 itself, rather than the device entry twice.

 And somehow your addition of the 'ContainsKey' check escaped my notice.
 This of course fixes the multiple Endpoint problem without the need for my
 path/name protection.

 So I've checked it and everything seems to work.  (There now seems to be a
 separate problem of interference between USB devices -- plugging in my
 Wacom seems to kill the MIDI stream rather quickly!  That's another
 ticket, though, when I have better data.)

 >
 > The other few minor changes were coding style:
 >  * no space between cast and variable
 >  * no space between type and asterisk
 >  * no space around expression
 >  * expand if else statement to 4 lines at least.

 I'm glad to note that all these -- aside from the if-else -- were in the
 code I inherited from you...! (:-))

--

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 28 14:58:18 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (anevilyak)
Date: Wed, 28 Oct 2009 13:58:18 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #2177: boot screen video mode
 incorrect/unsupported, but desktop okay
In-Reply-To: <038.d1bd554a50c472377b631d3cad48fc0e@haiku-os.org>
References: <038.d1bd554a50c472377b631d3cad48fc0e@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <047.d253b62f14bbd0239bab2b7e796d2ed5@haiku-os.org>

#2177: boot screen video mode incorrect/unsupported, but desktop okay
---------------------------------+------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  kev                 |       Owner:  axeld    
      Type:  bug                 |      Status:  reopened 
  Priority:  normal              |   Milestone:  R1       
 Component:  System/Boot Loader  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Resolution:                      |   Blockedby:           
  Platform:  x86                 |    Blocking:           
---------------------------------+------------------------------------------

Comment(by anevilyak):

 Replying to [comment:17 Kev]:
 > My bad, I thought the KERN messages indicated it was the kernel.  Sorry
 about that.  :)

 Those are indeed from the kernel, but those are the point at which the
 actual haiku graphics driver is setting the desktop resolution (i.e. end
 of boot screen/start of haiku desktop). There should be a similar
 EDID/resolution dump near the very beginning of the syslog, and that's the
 part that's relevant since that's where the boot loader's doing its work
 to set the resolution for the actual boot screen.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/2177#comment:18>

From trac at haiku-os.org  Wed Oct 28 15:06:57 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (streak)
Date: Wed, 28 Oct 2009 14:06:57 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4860: Tracker lost files with non standard
 names while moving them from bfs - ntfs
Message-ID: <041.807d5f54fdf7b6b54d7b9e4cfdf27a4b@haiku-os.org>

#4860: Tracker lost files with non standard names while moving them from bfs -
ntfs
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  streak           |       Owner:  nobody   
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Add-Ons/Tracker  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Tracker lost files with non standard names while moving them from bfs -
 ntfs

 If filename uses <?> [ nonstandard naming for example "jaka? ??dzka
 muzyczka.mp3" ] on bfs partition and i wanted to move it into ntfs
 partition tracker couldnt move it. Of course it monit that it cant move it
 [ because of nonstandard naming ] but after that tracker deletes the
 source file from BFS so file disappears from BFS and will not appear in
 NTFS partition.

 Definitelly a dangerous bug if you're keeping important files on bfs [
 documents ] and using non standard naming [ for example using polish
 alphabet ]

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4860>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------

 Component:  Servers/midi_server  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Resolution:  fixed                |   Blockedby:               
  Platform:  All                  |    Blocking:               
----------------------------------+-----------------------------------------
Changes (by phoudoin):

  * status:  assigned => closed
  * resolution:  => fixed


Comment:

 > I'm glad to note that all these -- aside from the if-else -- were
 > in the code I inherited from you...! (:-))

 Hum, no. My list above what not what was missing but what was espected.
 As in:
 {{{
 #!cpp
 -       ((DeviceWatcher*)data)->_ScanDevices(kDevicesRoot);
 +       ((DeviceWatcher*) data)->_ScanDevices(kDevicesRoot);
 }}}

 The space after cast is a coding style violation.

 {{{
 #!cpp
 -       if (fDeviceEndpointsMap.ContainsKey(path)) {
 +       if ( fDeviceEndpointsMap.ContainsKey(path) ) {
 }}}

 The space around expression too.

 {{{
 #!cpp
 -       DeviceEndpoints* deviceEndpoints = [...]
 +       DeviceEndpoints * deviceEndpoints = [...]
 }}}

 Space between type and asterisk is too.

 Wasn't the case in my code. That's pure luck maybe, as I'm not known
 for respecting well our coding style, but at least that was't there
 before.

 Anyway, I'm glad it's working fine with actual hardware, minus USB
 conflich with Wacom device (I've similar issue with USB keyboard and USB
 volito tablet too), but I'm closing this ticket now.

#4864: application/system crash(ports/registrar problem?)

 Reporter:  augiedoggie        |       Owner:  bonefish 
     Type:  bug                |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1

 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 When this problem occurs all currently running applications will just
 vanish when you attempt to use them and no new applications will launch.
 For example, trying to run lpe gives an error about bad port id.


 I first noticed this when running the ruby test suite, but now I've had it
 happen even during regular use of Haiku.  The ruby test suite is
 guaranteed to reproduce the problem.


 I'm attaching a verbatim copy of my syslog which gives some interesting
 error messages at the end.  There is a lot of noise in the syslog due to
 the fact that my computer is under almost constant ssh brute force
 attacks.


 I hate to file such a generic bug report, but my system becomes unusable
 when this starts happening so it's difficult to gather data.  Filing this
 one under Servers/registrar since I've seen some  really old bug reports
 where this was the problem.

 reaped/reclaimed (was: application/system crash(ports/registrar problem?))
In-Reply-To: <046.a0631e680983d339812398ab56807a40@haiku-os.org>
References: <046.a0631e680983d339812398ab56807a40@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <055.ec9ff8cabd918d0253a8facf63970d65@haiku-os.org>

#4864: message ports not being reaped/reclaimed
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
Changes (by augiedoggie):

  * owner:  bonefish => axeld
  * component:  Servers/registrar => System/Kernel


Comment:

 While running a 'watch listport' within a terminal I can see that running
 certain applications or when an application crashes the number of used
 ports doesn't go back down to the same number as before the application
 was started.  I think there is a gradual build up of these zombie ports
 which are not being reclaimed by the system.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4864#comment:1>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 29 04:29:02 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (augiedoggie)
Date: Thu, 29 Oct 2009 03:29:02 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4864: message ports not being
	reaped/reclaimed
In-Reply-To: <046.a0631e680983d339812398ab56807a40@haiku-os.org>
References: <046.a0631e680983d339812398ab56807a40@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <055.752abd9e6ee643ff38d670b524e0519d@haiku-os.org>

#4864: message ports not being reaped/reclaimed
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  augiedoggie    |       Owner:  axeld    
     Type:  bug            |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  System/Kernel  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                 |    Platform:  All      
 Blocking:                 |  
---------------------------+------------------------------------------------

Comment(by augiedoggie):

 Just to give some examples....

 The system "loses" 10 ports for each launch and quit of BeZilla, and at
 least 3 for each launch of the ruby interpreter.  Just running 'ruby' and
 then killing it with a Ctrl-C shows this behavior.

 I'm posting a copy of the ruby optional package [http://www.haiku-
 ports.de/packages/dev-lang/ruby/ruby-1.9.1-x86-gcc2-2009-10-28.zip here]
 in case someone would like to test with it. ''unzip -d /boot
 ruby-1.9.1-x86-gcc2-2009-10-28.zip'' to install.


 My system uses approximately 125-150 ports right after boot.  After
 running for a few hours, I have one BeZilla window and one Terminal window
 open, I'm seeing 440 ports used.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4864#comment:2>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 29 14:48:35 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (jackburton)
Date: Thu, 29 Oct 2009 13:48:35 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4777: DirectDaemon: failed to aquire
 direct sem: Bad semaphore ID
In-Reply-To: <042.4aada4a7a001bc0afb412e6be0154315@haiku-os.org>
References: <042.4aada4a7a001bc0afb412e6be0154315@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <051.174ca93733ec3b725271984c06e61639@haiku-os.org>

#4777: DirectDaemon: failed to aquire direct sem: Bad semaphore ID
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
  Reporter:  scottmc        |       Owner:  marcusoverhagen
      Type:  bug            |      Status:  closed         
  Priority:  normal         |   Milestone:  R1             
 Component:  Kits/Game Kit  |     Version:  R1/alpha1      
Resolution:  invalid        |   Blockedby:                 
  Platform:  All            |    Blocking:                 
----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------
Changes (by jackburton):

  * status:  new => closed
  * resolution:  => invalid


Comment:

 That's ok. That message is a debug leftover I introduced to track down a
 problem, and you see it (also) when a BDirectWindow application quits (the
 semaphore in question is deleted) or when an application uses a
 BDirectWindow without implementing the DirectConnection() function (like
 in libsdl).
 I'll just remove or conditionally include the log message, since it's not
 usually important for the end user.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4777#comment:2>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 teapot is not spinning.
In-Reply-To: <038.d49ba786099de323da8787be7b47fcb8@haiku-os.org>
References: <038.d49ba786099de323da8787be7b47fcb8@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <047.34c57fa75f2e8f77357ed4ad8ec6dec5@haiku-os.org>

#4355: GLTeapot stops rendering when teapot is not spinning.
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  bga              |       Owner:  jackburton   
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Kits/OpenGL Kit  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------

Comment(by jackburton):

 The problem is that the GL addon doesn't redraw to the screen if the
 teapot is not spinning: since nothing changed from the openGL POV, it
 doesn't trigger a redraw. To fix this, we could to copy the content of the
 openGL "front" buffer to the screen on every DirectConnected() (possible,
 but right now I don't know if there are drawbacks).

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4355#comment:2>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Thu Oct 29 16:34:09 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (jackburton)
Date: Thu, 29 Oct 2009 15:34:09 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4355: GLTeapot stops rendering when
 teapot is not spinning.
In-Reply-To: <038.d49ba786099de323da8787be7b47fcb8@haiku-os.org>
References: <038.d49ba786099de323da8787be7b47fcb8@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <047.c57db1eeaf6119b347bf07a81dfc2da3@haiku-os.org>

#4355: GLTeapot stops rendering when teapot is not spinning.
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  bga              |       Owner:  jackburton   
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Kits/OpenGL Kit  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------

Comment(by jackburton):

 And to add more info: while BGLView has a FrameResized() hook, it doesn't
 have a FrameMoved(). FrameResized(), in fact, triggers a redraw in the GL
 addon.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4355#comment:3>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 preference application, with white text, most GUI elements still render
 with black text, as if black text is hard coded. The expected result would

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 30 06:47:34 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (siarzhuk)
Date: Fri, 30 Oct 2009 05:47:34 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #2428: [sshd] can't start sshd
In-Reply-To: <040.3a7f0b60cf673f0880f4f3c0762b5bb8@haiku-os.org>
References: <040.3a7f0b60cf673f0880f4f3c0762b5bb8@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <049.38f2c29837359c1802401d325628a544@haiku-os.org>

#2428: [sshd] can't start sshd
----------------------------------------------+-----------------------------
  Reporter:  diver                            |       Owner:  axeld        
      Type:  bug                              |      Status:  reopened     
  Priority:  normal                           |   Milestone:  R1           
 Component:  Applications/Command Line Tools  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Resolution:                                   |   Blockedby:               
  Platform:  All                              |    Blocking:               
----------------------------------------------+-----------------------------

Comment(by siarzhuk):

 I think it was not "broken" because worked for me already about 3-4 month.
 The things to check:

 1) The access rights for the key files - only owner should can read and
 write them;

 2) Host files must be generated with correct options:

 {{{
 ssh-keygen -t dsa -f /boot/common/etc/ssh_host_dsa_key
 ssh-keygen -t rsa -f /boot/common/etc/ssh_host_rsa_key
 }}}

 3) Password for the user must be set to non-empty - just use "passwrd"
 command to changing it from default empty one to something meaningful.

 Hope it helps. :-)

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/2428#comment:9>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.


From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 30 13:03:43 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (myyr)
Date: Fri, 30 Oct 2009 12:03:43 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4873: 'ADI AD1986A SoundMax 6-channel HD'
 sound card forces Haiku to reboot
Message-ID: <039.cdee85aaeedbc20d1fb3f26bf19c60d4@haiku-os.org>

#4873: 'ADI AD1986A SoundMax 6-channel HD' sound card forces Haiku to reboot
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  myyr               |       Owner:  korli    
     Type:  bug                |      Status:  new      
 Priority:  normal             |   Milestone:  R1       
Component:  Drivers/Audio/HDA  |     Version:  R1/alpha1
Blockedby:                     |    Platform:  x86      
 Blocking:                     |  
-------------------------------+--------------------------------------------
 ASUS A8V-VM motherboard has integrated 'ADI AD1986A SoundMax 6-channel HD'
 sound card. If it's enabled in bios then Haiku will boot, load and then
 reboot the PC, right in the end of loading process. If audio is disabled
 in bios, Haiku works. Same outcome if Haiku is running from live-CD or
 installed on hard-drive.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4873>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

From trac at haiku-os.org  Fri Oct 30 15:02:11 2009
From: trac at haiku-os.org (phoudoin)
Date: Fri, 30 Oct 2009 14:02:11 -0000
Subject: [Haiku-bugs] [Haiku] #4355: GLTeapot stops rendering when
 teapot is not spinning.
In-Reply-To: <038.d49ba786099de323da8787be7b47fcb8@haiku-os.org>
References: <038.d49ba786099de323da8787be7b47fcb8@haiku-os.org>
Message-ID: <047.6cb46e1d2eefbddab3fdcbdc88135cdc@haiku-os.org>

#4355: GLTeapot stops rendering when teapot is not spinning.
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------
 Reporter:  bga              |       Owner:  jackburton   
     Type:  bug              |      Status:  new          
 Priority:  normal           |   Milestone:  R1           
Component:  Kits/OpenGL Kit  |     Version:  R1/pre-alpha1
Blockedby:                   |    Platform:  All          
 Blocking:                   |  
-----------------------------+----------------------------------------------

Comment(by phoudoin):

 Replying to [comment:3 jackburton]:
 > And to add more info: while BGLView has a FrameResized() hook, it
 doesn't have a FrameMoved(). FrameResized(), in fact, triggers a redraw in
 the GL addon.
 >

 FrameMoved() is not needed because the GL viewport properties won't change
 when the view is moved. If our app_server trigger a full redraw on view
 move, it's a bug with app_server from which we expect to "bitblit" as much
 as possible the view content on move, invalidating only the previous
 invisible part.

 Regarding the black background, we do have an issue regard the
 transparent/non transparent color and our currently forced single-buffer
 rendering.
 I've other few majors bugs too, which I will create a ticket for,
 regarding multiple GLView support and creation/destruction issue.

 OpenGL Kit is not ready for R1 in his current shape.

-- 
Ticket URL: <http://dev.haiku-os.org/ticket/4355#comment:4>
Haiku <http://dev.haiku-os.org>
The Haiku operating system.

 Reporter:  streak                |       Owner:  axeld

 Priority:  normal                |   Milestone:  R1

 Blocking:                        |

 folder

 for example, while we have a folder with these content:

 /examplefilder
 |-file1.txt
 |-file2.txt
 |-file3.txt
 |-file4.txt

 and we moving it into BFS partition tracker's skipping few files inside
 "examplefolder" and on BFS partition we have incompleted folder structure
 after moving whole folder from NTFS:

 /examplefilder
 |-file1.txt
 |-file3.txt
